lessons.name: Congratulations and Welcome
lessons.description: Congratulations and Welcome to the Footwork Fastlane! You're about to build your footwork from the ground up, and I'll be there to guide you every step of the way.

sentences.text: Congratulations and welcome to the Footwork Fastlane.
You're about to take your badminton and footwork to a level that you've never realised was possible, and I'm going to guide you every step of the way.
The fact that you're here tells me you're not only fiercely dedicated to improving your badminton, you also want to approach it in a very smart way.
You see, too many players say they want to get better at Bamboaton, but they're not willing to put in the time and hard work that it takes to get there.
They look up to players like Lindan Li Chungwei and Kento Momota, but they never take the time to realise how many years of hard work and sacrifices it's taken them to get there.
Too many players spend their time learning trickshots or other useless skills when they aren't even able to perform the fundamental Balmont and techniques at a sufficient level.
By enrolling in this course, you're putting yourself in the top percentile of badminton players who don't just say they want to improve their ballot and they actually do something about it.
And let me just tell you that you've made an incredibly smart decision.
Top players and coaches all agree that the best way to improve your badminton isn't your smash, isn't your racket, isn't your backhand, it's your footwork.
In fact, one of the top posts on the badminton Central forums explains this exact concept.
Posted all the way back in 2013, this is one of the most popular threads on the forum with over 300 replies and almost 4000 views.
Now if this sounds strange to you, let me explain why footwork is the most effective way to improve your game.
This information comes from an unlikely source, Mohamed Ali.
Now I'm not particularly interested in combat sports, but the legacy that Muhammad Ali left transcends the game as the greatest boxer of all time.
I've often wondered what is it that sets him apart from the competition?
At first, I assumed he could punch harder than the other athletes.
After all, boxing is a knockout sport and having a knockout punch is considered to be a big deal.
But after having a closer look, I realised there was more to it.
There's this famous quote from Ali.
I believe this first part, Float like a Butterfly, is what makes Ali such a successful boxer.
Take a look at the absolute gracefulness Ali demonstrates as he dodges all of his opponent's punches.
This takes an incredible amount of speed, agility and precision to pull off one small misstep and he'll be in big trouble.
But this unique ability to outmanoeuvre his opponents cemented his legacy as the greatest boxer of all time.
Now back to badminton.
We put a lot of focus on the smash.
When you watch the top players battle out on court, we're really drawn to the powerful jump smash that ends the rally and secures the gold medal.
This is a lot like focusing on the knockout punch.
Sure it's important.
But the true secret to success lies on a much deeper level.
Before the rallies ended with a smash, the two players are locked into a fierce battle of trying to outmanoeuvre each other on court.
The players know that this is where the true battle takes place.

If your opponent is running circles around you, just like Ali would do in the ring, then it doesn't matter how powerful your smashes, you still end up in defeat because you'd never get the chance to unleash your knockout punch.
Do you ever watch a game of Bamboaton and notice a huge skill disparity between the two players?
Even if you didn't know what the score was and only saw a few rallies, you would have a pretty good idea who was winning the game.
A big part of the reason we can instantly spot when one player is much more skilled than another is because of their movement.
Let me show you an example here.
Lee Jon Wei is sparring against a less experienced player.
Keep your attention on this player for now.
Now, while he's still definitely playing at a high level, he's clearly outclassed when compared Lee Chong Wei.
Watch this rally and look at his movement.
Just from this one thing, you can tell that he's working at maximum intensity but is still really struggling under Licheon weighs pressure.
Now let's watch that same rally again, but this time focus on Licheong Wei.
You should instantly be able to see the difference.
Notice that he's moving in a way that's relaxed and casual, almost like he isn't even trying.
And yet he's still in complete control.
Always getting to the shuttle early and dictating the pace of the rally.
That's the difference that good footwork makes.
At this point, you're probably thinking, if good footwork can really improve my game that quickly, then why don't people spend more time working on it?
Simply put, footwork is hard.
I won't lie to you.
Even though I've designed the footwork fast Lane to make this process as easy as possible for you, it's still going to take a lot of work.
Footwork is a very broad subject, and there's simply a lot of techniques and information that you need to learn.
Because of this, it's going to take a lot of time and practise to complete the course.
Remember, I'm packing ten years of knowledge into the footwork fast Lane, so you're not going to become a master overnight.
This also leads to a lot of conflicting information.

Back in the day when I was trying to teach myself footwork using the internet, I found it incredibly frustrating because I stumbled across a forum that said one thing, and then I find a website that told me something completely different.
When there's so much conflicting information on footwork, it leads to players getting frustrated, overwhelmed, and giving up.
Also, a lot of people just don't find footwork exciting, so instead, they focus on the more fun aspects, like smashes fancy trick shots.
Or maybe they don't even train at all and just play games.
Why can't I win any games?
Well, there's certainly nothing wrong with this approach if you're just trying to have fun.
It's a terrible way to actually get better at badminton.
So if footwork is difficult to learn for these three reasons, then what does that mean for you?
Well, the fact that you're here tells me you've got your priorities in the right place.
You would rather get real results than focus on flashy shots so that's one box checked off.
Until now, there's never been a single comprehensive resource that teaches you everything you need to know about footwork.
Trust me, I spent a lot of time searching for it.
Most of the time, opposing advice occurs because footwork is such a huge topic, you can't cover it all in one blog post or one YouTube video, so advice often gets taken out of context.
That's why I wanted to create an allencompassing course that teaches you everything you need to know or giving each little detail the attention that it deserves.

In situations where there are multiple correct ways of doing something, I'll be able to give you a full explanation so you'll know exactly what the options are and how to choose between them based on the situation.
I've taken care to ensure that all the information in the footwear fast Lane is coherent, so you should never feel like you're being given conflicting information.
Also, by putting all this in one resource, I'm going to save you hundreds of hours of trawling through Internet forums.
You're welcome.
Finally, I mentioned that footwork is just a difficult topic to learn, and nothing's going to change that.
But luckily for you, there's this concept that I like to call grindy versus complex difficulty.
Let me explain.
Imagine if I said I'd give you a million dollars if you could solve this incredibly complex physics equation.
Unless your name is Albert Einstein, there's no way you'd be successful.
No matter how much effort you put in.
This is complex difficulty.
You have no idea where to start or how to solve the problem.
The only way you could approach it would be to spend years and years studying physics before even attempting the challenge.
Now, what if I offered you the same million dollars, but this time with a different challenge?
I'm going to give you a large textbook filled with simple math questions like two plus five, and it's your job to complete it.
This is an example of grinding difficulty.
It's still difficult.
It's going to take a lot of work to go through the whole textbook.
But if I offered you the choice between the first and the second challenge, which one would you pick?
Obviously the second one.
It might take some serious dedication, but as long as you put in the time, you're practically guaranteed to win the million dollars.
It's a lot more achievable, and anyone can do it now.
Back to footwork.
The reason it's so difficult is because it's both grindy and complex.
So for most people who aren't child prodigies and who haven't been training with a private coach since the age of four, it's simply too difficult to learn.
Not impossible, just very hard.
But you're one of the lucky individuals who have enrolled in the football fast Lane.
This is an incredible advantage.
I've taken away all the complex difficulty and condensed all of my knowledge into a step by step process for you to follow.
All that's left for you to tackle is the grinding aspect of it, which might take some time but is a lot easier.
Look, I had to learn all this the hard way grindy and complex since I had no one to go to and no one to teach me this stuff.
This took me multiple years, so to be honest, I'm pretty jealous of you.
And like I said, this opportunity has never existed before to anyone without a coach or a dedicated trainer.
It's the absolute first of its kind, and that's why I was so passionate about creating this course in the first place.
I've taken a process that took me multiple years to learn, with countless headaches along the way into a structured system that anyone could follow.

Imagine yourself being able to move around a band court with blistering speed, playing with relentless aggression, and never giving your opponents an inch of breathing room, or rapidly moving around the four corners of the court when you're under pressure, miraculously being able to return everything your opponent throws at you.
This will all be possible when you go through the footwork Fastlane, as long as you're willing to put in the time and work.
I've designed this course to make the process as easy as possible for you, just like answering two plus five, but at the end of the day, you still have to work through the textbook yourself.
If you want to win a million dollars in the footwork Fastlane instead of simple maths questions, your job will be to work through the accelerator worksheets.
Let me quickly explain how these work.
Each lesson will come with an attached PDF accelerator worksheet, as well as giving you a concise summary of the information.
In each video, you'll be given an assignment.
Do not skip these.
Each assignment will be related to the topic covered in each video.
It will give you actionable steps to guide you through this footwork journey.
Although they do take some work, all of the assignments are super simple and are accessible to players of any skill level.
They're also very specific, so you should never feel lost on what to do next.
But although they're simple, you still have to go through them all.
I've made it as easy as possible for you, but you still have to put in the time and work to apply the lessons you've learnt.
Think of it like this back when you were a kid, you probably didn't know how to ride a bike, so every time you went to the park, you would go there with your parents and practise.
You might have fallen over a lot of times, and it might have taken a while, but eventually, by constantly trying to ride a bike, you eventually learn how to do it.

But what if instead of going out to the park and actually riding a bike, you spend hours and hours at home reading articles, blog posts, and watching instructional YouTube videos on how to ride a bike?
Would you expect that to be an effective learning method?
Of course not.
The point is, it doesn't matter how much time you spend consuming theory, you have to actually put it in action.
Learning footwork is the exact same.
To be honest, you could binge watch this course in one day if you wanted to, but that wouldn't get you anywhere.
If that's all you did a year down the line, you won't have made any improvements in your footwork.
You'd still be in the exact same place at the exact same skill level.
So that's why I've created these assignments.
I want to give you a clear roadmap to follow so you're always applying what you learn into real on court skills.
I really can't stress enough how important these accelerated worksheets are along with the video lessons.
This is my way of literally holding your hand through the entire journey.
I want you to know I'm going to be there with you every step of the way, even if things get difficult.
But honestly, the hard work has already been done for you, so all you have to do is follow the step by step system and you're guaranteed to be successful.
These are so important.
I actually recommend you don't go on to the next video lesson until you've completed the previous assignment.
It will take longer to go through the course this way, but it will be so worth it since each lesson builds on top of knowledge that you've already learned.
And remember, it took me years of trial and error to learn all this stuff.
So even if it takes you a few months to complete the course, that's still incredibly quick for the sheer amount of content that you're going to be learning.
I'm going to be teaching you everything you need to know about footwork, which is a huge topic.
So on that note, I want to give you your first assignment for the course.
Since this is just the first lesson, I'll give you an easy one.
In fact, you don't even have to get off your couch.
First, I want you to watch this video of Lichenwe playing against Kenichi Tago.
It'll be linked in the worksheet below.
I want you to watch the video from start to finish.
Now, it's no secret that Lee Jungwe has incredible footwork, but what's unique here is the camera angle.
It's framed from an up close side on angle so you can really appreciate the speed and skill that he's moving with.
Once you've done that, I want you to answer a question.
Get out a piece of pen and paper or open up a word document, whichever you prefer.
Answer this question.
What are your core motivators for enrolling in this course?
Remember, your core motivators are the things that drive you.
It's important to write this down somewhere since this is what's going to keep you motivated and driven as you work through the course.
Is there a certain rival you want to be?
Do you want to win a tournament or join a certain badminton team?
Is there a particular area of footwork that really frustrates you and you've been dying to solve?
Do you play badminton for fun, competitively or maybe even one day hopes to become a professional player in badminton and life as a whole?
The why is usually just as important as the what when you truly, deeply understand why you're doing something, success goes from being a possibility to a guarantee.
Spend a good amount of time thinking about this before you write it down, I want you to be as detailed as possible.
I also recommend that you post your answer in the comment section so we can build an awesome supportive community of players who are driven to get results.
Make sure you complete this assignment before moving on to the next video.
I'm so excited to begin this journey with you.

lessons.name: You Can Do It
lessons.description: Everyone has excuses. The difference between the best badminton players vs average ones is simple: they don't let their excuses stop them. You will be successful as long as you put in the work.

lessons.name: The Five Footwork Functions
lessons.description: Everyone wants to have good footwork, but what exactly does that mean? These five functions define how effective a player's footwork is.

sentences.text: We've spent a lot of time talking about why footwork is so important, but what's the actual difference between good and bad footwork?
What are the exact traits that make someone's footwork good?
We can break this down into the five foot work functions.
This is important to understand and because before we actually start working on our footwork, we need to know what the end goal is.
Sure, we want to move faster on court, but there's more to it than that.
I want you to understand all of the specifics, because everything you do from here on should relate back to the five foot work functions.
The five foot work functions are speed, efficiency, recovery, shot pressure and safety.
First, we have speed.
I don't suppose this is particularly new information.
Obviously, it gives us a huge advantage if we can move around the court faster than our opponents.
This speed allows us to retrieve shots we otherwise wouldn't be able to, as well as being more threatening on the attack.
Surprisingly fast footwork doesn't rely so much on things like sprinting speed.
In fact, it's almost entirely down to your technique.
When you watch professionals play, especially from a close up angle, it's mind boggling how quickly they're able to move around the court.
They somehow have this unique ability to make a badminton court look tiny, even though most amateur players struggle to get from one corner to another in time for the shuttle.
This is so important for high level badminton, where the pace of the game is incredibly quick and you see this at every level of the game.
As you get better and better, the pace of the rallies will start to increase.
So in order to keep up with this pace, you have to increase the speed of your footwork efficiency.
Good footwork also has to be efficient.
This means moving around the court at a certain intensity while using the least amount of energy possible.
Again, using the correct technique goes a long way in being efficient since it allows you to take advantage of your body's biomechanics in the smartest way possible.
When you watch the professionals, they're not just fast, they look like they're gliding around the court, making it effortless.
In reality, playing at this level is incredibly tiring, but their footwork makes it look easy.
That's because they've learnt to move in the most efficient way possible.
When you're playing at such a high intensity, it's important that not a drop of energy gets wasted.

You'll sometimes even see players walking in court, which might seem counterintuitive to the first function, but that's because they're great at identifying opportunities where it's more important to be efficient and fast, so use it as a chance to save energy recovery.
So many players move quickly to the shuttle, but then lazily watch their own shot and don't get back in position for the reply.
Good footwork isn't just about getting to the shuttle quickly, it's about seamlessly transitioning.
One movement into the next.
Even if you're great at moving to the shuttle quickly, if you sacrifice your ability to recover, then you'll still be in a lot of trouble.
And it's not just about frantically getting back to the middle of the court after every shot.
Good recovery is more advanced than that.
It's about transitioning effectively out of the shot and moving to a dynamic base that puts you in a good position for the reply through anticipation shot pressure.
Good footwork doesn't just get you to the shuttle, it also allows you to play better shots.
To give you an example, the number one thing I say to beginners who want to improve their backhand clear is to get better footwork.
Now, that might sound sarcastic, but it really is more important to focus on, especially for a beginner.
The only reason you had to play a backhand was because you were slow to the shuttle.
Work on your footwork and you'll be able to get around the shuttle instead and play a around the head forehand shot.
So it doesn't even matter if your backhand is weak.
But it's not just about the backhand, and it's not just about beginners.
Every single shot in badminton will be executed at a higher quality when footwork improves.
That's pretty cool if you think about it.
By going through this course, you actually start playing better quality shots without us even having to work on it.
It's kind of like magic.
That's all because of one simple concept that we're able to play better shots when we reach the shuttle earlier in the rear court.
This lets us get our body behind the shuttle, which has a tremendous impact on power and control.
Try playing a smash or clear like this and it will feel pretty easy.
But do the same thing again when the shuttle is past your body and you'll definitely struggle a lot more.
This is also true at the front of the court.
Getting to the shuttle early allows you to play the shot from up here instead of down here.
As you can imagine, this makes a huge difference to the quality of the shot and how much pressure you're able to exert.
Finally, safety the most important but overlooked footwork function.
I get it.
Talking about safety isn't as sexy as talking about jump smashes, and I certainly don't want to sound like your parents.
But safety is really so important and think of it like this.
Besides the obvious dangers, staying safe means you don't get injured, which means you get to play more balmotal.
A few years ago, I injured myself really badly.
It wasn't to do with footwork, but it made me appreciate the importance of taking care of myself.
Instead of taking the time to rest and recover from my injury, which I should have done, I just ignored it and decided to keep playing.

This took something that would have been a minor issue and made it a chronic injury that I still suffer from to this day I won't go into too much detail but it was extremely stressful and it was a huge part of the reason I ended up taking a three year break from badminton I want to emphasise that playing Bambitan without the correct footwork increases your chances of injury a lot I know people who have broken their ankle or torn their Achilles.

Now I certainly don't want to scare you because these are very rare isolated incidents but I hope it helps you realise the importance of good technique and how it can drastically lower the chance of this happening to you I want you to keep in mind the five foot work functions as you work through the course every lesson relates back to these in some way and as you work through the course you should see a drastic improvement in all five functions this is how you know you're on the right track taking the first few steps to becoming a footwork master to recap the five footwork functions are speed the ability to move around the court quickly efficiency the ability to work at a certain intensity while spending the least amount of energy recovery the ability to effectively reposition after each shot shot pressure to be in an optimal position to enable a high quality shot safety so you don't get injured keep working towards these goals and you'll never stray too far off the path to success.

lessons.name: Muscle Memory
lessons.description: How are the world's top performers able to be so...excellent? It all comes down a deceptively simple concept called muscle memory.

sentences.text: When you see what humans are capable of, frankly, it's kind of mindblowing.
How are certain individuals able to execute high performance tasks with such speed and precision?
When you think about it, it almost seems like a superpower.
And honestly, it kind of is.
Every jawdropping performance, sport, or skill was made possible by a spectacular phenomenon called muscle memory.
This is something we're all capable of, and it's so important that I've dedicated an entire lesson to it.
I briefly mentioned that the goal of the footwork Fastlane is to get you to commit these techniques to muscle memory.
But what exactly does that mean?
What is muscle memory?
As spectacular as some of the results might be, the actual concept behind it is surprisingly simple.
If you repeat a specific action enough times, a long term muscle memory is created for that task, eventually allowing it to be performed without conscious effort.
This process decreases the need for attention and creates maximum efficiency in the memory and motor systems.
Basically, once you develop the muscle memory for a task, you'll be able to do it without even thinking about it.
We depend on muscle memory all the time in our day to day lives.
Like I mentioned, a perfect example of this is your ability to ride a bike, even if you haven't cycled for years.
As soon as you hop onto a bike, that process will come back to you immediately and it will feel completely natural.
If it wasn't for muscle memory, you'd have to relearn the process of riding a bike like a child every time.
There's probably a few other examples of muscle memory that you've developed in your life.
Typing.
We start off having to find each key on the keyboard, but soon learn to touch type without even thinking about what our fingers are doing.
Driving remember awkwardly fumbling around each time you sat behind the wheel, and yet soon after, it becomes a natural process.
Video Games When you first pick up a game, you're struggling to fumble around the controls, but after a short amount of time, you're poning nudes with 360 no scopes.

Think about how easy all these tasks become after the initial learning process, and maybe these examples don't all apply to you, but you should be able to appreciate the difference when you apply a task to muscle memory.
What I'm trying to show you is the same principle that makes these incredible feats possible isn't actually a rare thing.
All of us take advantage of muscle memory in our day to day lives.
It's something that we're born with.
As long as you put the time and effort into a specific task, you will develop the muscle memory to become extremely proficient.
As you can imagine, muscle memory plays a huge part in badminton.
When he's on court winning Olympic medals, do you think Lindan stops to think what the correct footwork is?
Do you think he pauses to consider whether he's just stuck with his left leg or his right leg?
Of course not.
That would be a terrible way to play badminton.
Whenever you see a skilled badminton player, you know for sure that they've spent many years training.
As a result, every situation that comes up is something they've practised many times, so they've built up the muscle memory.
This is what enables them to look fluent and natural in court compared to a beginner who looks clumsy and uncoordinated.
But even if you don't expect to be at the next Olympic Games, if you want to get better at footwork, you need to develop the muscle memory.
You need to get to a point where you can execute the techniques without even thinking about it.
And I admit it's going to take some work.
There's no shortcut to developing muscle memory.
It's all about getting in quality repetitions.
At first it'll be difficult.
You'll struggle to do things correctly, and it may be a little overwhelming.
But take your time in the footwork Fastlane.
You'll be encouraged to break down information into easily digestible chunks.
So before you do an assignment, try to practise everything at a slow pace that allows you to keep everything under control.
Don't worry if it takes you a while before you're comfortable working at full speed, it's more important to make sure you're doing everything correctly and get in those quality repetitions.
If you focus on the quality, you'll soon become muscle memory, and then you can start increasing the speed while maintaining good technique.
The goal of this course is to develop your muscle memory for Bandit and footwork.
I've structured it so each lesson builds on top of stuff that you've already learnt.
Because of this, I highly recommend that you work through the assignments in order because you'll need the correct foundation before you build to the more advanced assignments.
The assignments themselves are actually quite short because they mostly revolve around the Swift checklist, but for most of you, you may need to add in extra repetitions before you feel confident.
If this is the case, I don't only allow it, I highly recommend it.
The truth is, people are entering the footwork Fastlane at different skill levels, so it might take one student longer to commit something to muscle memory compared to another.
That's why I've included the bare minimum of practise into these assignments.
I'm relying on you to take charge of your own training.
If you go through an assignment but don't feel like you've committed that technique to muscle memory yet, that's okay.
Spend as much time as necessary repeating the same drills until it does.
How do you know when something's become muscle memory?
Well, you should be able to judge for yourself quite accurately.
It essentially depends on two things.
One, you can execute the technique correctly.
This should be easy to judge for yourself by referring to the slow motion demonstration and Swift checklists.
Two, you're able to execute without thinking your body does the movement naturally without a conscious effort.
Remember, you need both these things to be there in order to consider a technique.
Muscle memory.
It's no good being able to do something without thinking if you're doing the wrong thing.
Because of this, it will take a while to complete the footwork Fastlane for most players.
If this is the case for you, don't be disheartened.
Just because the course is a few hours long doesn't mean I expect you to finish in a day.
The goal here is to build your footwork from the ground up.
Even if you don't know anything about footwork, by the end you'll be extremely proficient.
This is essentially ten years of footwork knowledge condensed into one course and footwork is an absolutely huge topic.
It would take months with a private coach to cover everything that we're going to learn.
That's not because private coaches are bad.
That's just how long it takes considering the amount of information in this course.
The point is I don't want you to become discouraged.
To take skill at anything takes a lot of time.
All of these people had to start somewhere and it certainly wasn't easy.
Anything worth having in life takes a lot of time, but I can assure you it will be absolutely worth it.
When you go through the entire course and commit everything to muscle memory, the results will be astounding.
I guarantee you won't even be able to recognise yourself from where you've started.
If you want to move around the court with blistering speed and precision, Then I can't overemphasise how valuable this course will be to you.
And because of that, I have an assignment for you.
Before you move on to the meat and potatoes of the course in module two, I want you to take the time to record yourself playing badminton.
It can be a real match or if you prefer, you can just shadow yourself playing Balmin.
You don't need a fancy camera or anything.
Just a camera on your smartphone is perfectly fine.
You can ask a friend to help you record or you can buy a cheap tripod of Amazon And just stick it in the corner.
If for some reason you feel awkward filming yourself, Then don't be.
This is something that top athletes use all the time in order to analyse their own gameplay.
It's really not something out of the ordinary.
The reason for this is I want you to have something to look back to when you complete the course.
I won't go into too much, much detail Because I don't want to ruin the surprise.
But for every student I've done with this, they have been absolutely amazed at the end.
Spend some time doing that assignment before moving on to the next module.
I can't wait for you to go through this course.

lessons.name: Building Blocks of Footwork
lessons.description: The 8 building blocks are the individual elements needed to build beautiful footwork. A player must master all 8 to technical precision before they can become proficient.

sentences.text: Hopefully at this point you understand why footwork is so important.
Every other part of your game builds off your movement.
So I found that developing a player's footwork is the quickest way to accelerate their boundaries and skills.
In this module, I'm going to teach you the eight building blocks of footwork are distinct elements that you need to learn.
They're called building blocks because you learn them individually and then put them together like bricks in a building.
These are the foundations that we're going to build your footwork on.
The first two building blocks are the stance and the split step.
These are positional building blocks.
Next we have running steps and chassis steps.
These are movement building blocks.
And finally we have the Lunge Physic, China Jump and Net Jump.
These are finishing building blocks.
We're going to spend an entire lesson on each of these because they're incredibly important.
I'm going to teach you how to build them from the ground up and then give you assignments to practise and make sure you're doing them correctly.
In my experience playing and coaching Bamboost for over ten years, I've noticed that a lot of players have picked up really bad habits that they aren't even aware of.
So for that reason, I want you to forget everything you've learned going through this module and build everything with me from the ground up.

If you think that these building blocks are really basic and you can already do them, then that's even more of a reason to pay attention to this module, since you may be making mistakes that you aren't even aware of.
Even though I know there's a temptation to jump right into the fun stuff, mastering the eight building blocks is essential.
If you are building a house, you need to first spend some time making sure that all the bricks were up to standard.
If you didn't and build a house with crumbly bricks, the whole building would just collapse.
So sure, if you jump right into footwork, you might get a small head start.
But eventually that's going to catch up with you down the line and you'll have to start from square one.
Imagine a complex gymnastics routine, the one with the tight leotards, breathtaking backflips and death defying formations.
Now imagine if you wanted to try out gymnastics and went to your local club for the first time.
I certainly would walk straight back out the door if the coach told me I had to try this on my first session.
And that makes sense.
Every single gymnast in this video started off learning simple techniques like planks, push ups and pull ups.
So why should Bambin be any different?
You can't jump into the more advanced stuff until you master the basics.
If you're serious about improving Abomination, I want you to pay attention to this module.
This could be the most important thing you learn.
In the next module, you'll be learning how to combine these to start travelling effectively to all corners of the badminton court.
But you can't do that until you've mastered the basics.
So I'll see you in the next video where we'll go over the first building block of footwork that starts.

lessons.name: Stance
lessons.description: Building block number 1. A player's stance is the way they position themself before moving to the shuttle. Since everything flows from the stance, an optimised stance affects all aspects of footwork.

sentences.text: When you're in a badminton rally, you're either hitting the shuttle or waiting for your opponent to hit the shuttle.
The way that you stand when your opponent is hitting the shuttle is called your stance, and it's the subtle but very important part of footwork.
Imagine a situation where you play a lift and your opponent it's about to fire off a powerful jump.
Smash.
Which version of me do you think has a better chance of returning the smash?
The one where I stand like this or the one where I stand like this?
That's an extreme example, but there's actually a lot of thought that goes into crafting this stance.
It's not just enough to be alert, there's a few specific things that you need to be doing.
So I want to start this lesson off by saying the exact stance depends on the situation of the Rally.
There isn't just one stance you can use for all situations.
Rather, you have to adapt it after every shot.
But with that in mind, I'm going to teach you the most important stance, which is the Neutral stance.
Not only is this stance the most frequently used, it forms a good base to build other stances off.
We use the neutral stance when the Rally is in an even state.
This means neither player is at an advantage or disadvantage.
An example of a neutral situation would be if me and my opponent were playing clears back and forth to each other.
Since neither of us are in a huge amount of trouble and neither of us can just win the Rally outright.
An example of a situation that isn't neutral would be if one player has the upper hand and is smashing from the half court.
The majority of the Rally will be in a fairly neutral situation, which is why the Neutral stance is the most commonly used for the Neutral stance.
You want to stand with your feet almost side by side, but with your racket foot slightly ahead.
If you're right handed, this means your right foot.
The distance between them should be a little wider than shoulder width.
From here, you need to bend your knees to lower your centre of gravity.
As you do this, shift your weight forward slightly.
Essentially, you want to be on your toes.
You should be holding your racket around waist height and slightly in front of you.
Don't hold it too much on the forehand side, and don't hold it too much on the backhand side.
Somewhere in the middle is best.
Also, make sure there's some space between you and the racket.
If you look at my starts from the side, you'll notice there's a good amount of distance between my body and my racket.
You definitely don't need to deliberately reach out, but also avoid the mistake of being too cramped inwards.
Your non racket arm is also important to consider.
Even though it doesn't do anything, you don't want to leave it down to the side.
How odd does this look?
The left arm plays an important part in balancing your body, so you want to position it like this from here.
My legs are positioned in a way that I can quite comfortably reach any corner, and my racket is in a good position to return those shots.
That's what makes the neutral stance such a good general option.
But like I said, there are times where you're going to have to adjust this stance.
The most obvious situation is when you're defending.
Let's say you played a weak lift and your opponent is about to smash.
In this situation, you need to alter your stance to get lower than before.
You can do this by bending your knees and widening your feet.
You also want to bring your racket down lower, since this puts it in the best position to defend a steep smash, which will end up landing somewhere around here.
This dance is great for defending smashes, but the trade off is it's very difficult to move forwards or backwards, so it certainly isn't a replacement for the neutral stance.
You'll see this defensive stance a lot in doubles, since the nature of the game means one pair will frequently be defending multiple smashes in a row.
The other notable example would be if you were in a flat exchange.
This means me and my opponent are playing drives back and forth to each other.
This is very common in doubles, but also occurs in singles.
Since these rallies are very fast and flat, it's not good enough to keep your racket down at your waist.

Instead, you want to bring it up to your head, since this puts it in the optimal position to return drives from there's so little time to react during these rallies, so keeping your racket up by your head means you can play drives without having to bring your racket up and down after every shot.

These are two stances that look very different to the neutral stance, so I wanted to bring them up to give you an understanding of why you'll see band players standing differently depending on the situation.
But don't worry, you don't have to learn all of these.
Right now, I just need you to focus on learning the neutral stance.
Not only is it the most important and frequently used, once you master it, you'll naturally start to adapt it to different situations.
To recap these concepts, I want to show you Lee Chongwe's neutral stance.
Notice that he is implementing all the key points I brought up in this lesson.
His feet are slightly wider than shoulder width apart, and his right foot is slightly ahead of his left foot.
He's lowering his centre of gravity by bending his knees, and notice how he has more weight resting on his toes than his heels.
His racket is held in a middle position in front of him, not on the forehand side and not on the backhand side.
It's also at waist height, and there's plenty of room between his body and his racket.
His left arm is out to the side to help him balance.
Your first assignment is to master the neutral stance.
This is the first assignment of the course that's going to actually require you to get off the couch and do some work.
I hope this excites you.
The fastest and most effective way to get better at Bamboaton is to practise these concepts yourself.
I've carefully designed these assignments to give you the fastest possible track to success, but it's completely dependent on you actually doing them.
These assignments are based on the methods I've developed coaching countless players over the years, so you can rest assured that the assignments will work as long as you do.
I understand the temptation to just binge watch all the lessons, but this is a video course to improve your footwork.
It's not Netflix.
Ideally, you want to complete each assignment before moving on to the next lesson, but I understand this might not be possible if you have limited access to a balance of court.
Either way, I want you to prioritise and go into all of these assignments with 100% effort.
If anything, I think they're more important than the lessons themselves because you have to practise it yourself.
And remember, if you go through an assignment and you don't feel like you've been able to commit it to muscle memory, feel free to go through it as many times as needed.
For this assignment, I want you to grab your balance and racket and practise the neutral stance.
In fact, you don't even have to be on a balance and call for this.
You can just do it in your living room, use the tips in this video, or cheque out the worksheet to recap what you've learned, and then try it yourself.
Once you think you've got it right, take a picture of your neutral stance.
Like I said, it's extremely important to take pictures of yourself.
Otherwise, it's hard to know if you're doing things correctly and it doesn't take any fancy equipment.
Just use the camera on your smartphone and ask a friend to help you out.
Or you can buy a tripod of Amazon.
You'll need to do this for all of the checklists.
If you try to do it without a video or picture to reference, you're just going to be guessing based on what you think you're doing.
But going by feeling is a horrible way of self assessment.
Every time I've gotten a student to record themselves playing Balmotan, their minds are blown up.
What they saw, what they were actually doing, was so different to what they thought they were doing.
So take the picture you just took and run it through the Swift checklist.
These checklists are the equivalent of having me there in person with you, giving you live feedback.
Think about how valuable that is.

If you pass this Swift checklist with no issues then Congratulations you're ready to move on to the next lesson but if the checklist points out any issues with your stance be sure to correct them before moving on.
Take another picture and run it through the checklist until you're given the green light.
If you want extra credit instead of just taking a picture you can film a video of you playing a real banana match and then pause it and take a snapshot of when you're in your neutral stance.
The reason this is useful is because it's very easy to make sure you're doing everything correctly when you have all the time in the world to think about what you're doing.

But in a high pressure situation like a game of amateur this can sometimes go out the window so it's another useful resource to cheque with recording a video gives you the most accurate assessment of your stance.
As I mentioned before mostly assignments from this point onwards are going to follow a similar process.
They're also going to get more complicated so this is a good way to get into the groove of things.
Once you've passed the assignment, Congratulations you've learnt the neutral stance which is something you're going to be using time and time again in your bandwidth and games.
This is also the first of the eight building blocks so you've set yourself up nicely for the rest of the module.
In the next lesson we'll continue to build your footwork with the split step.
This is a technique that allows us to change direction and move to corners explosively it's so subtle you may have never realised it even existed.
I'll see you there.

lessons.name: Split Step
lessons.description: Building block number 3. The split step first slips by unnoticed, but is a crucial element of badminton footwork. It enables fast, explosive movements from the base position as well as a momentum "reset". A secret ingredient for sure.

sentences.text: In the last lesson we learned, the neutral stance.
This is the best position to react your opponent's shot from.
But there's also a secret ingredient that I didn't mention.
This ingredient is what allows pro players to move so explosively from their base position and it's how they change direction so quickly.
It's a very small move movement, so it slips under the radar.
For most people, it's called the split step.
It's a small hop that we do before travelling to the shuttle.
It seems like a minor thing, but it's very important.
In this lesson, I'm going to show you how using the splitsp can give you an almost unfair advantage over the competition when implemented correctly.
In badminton, we only ever cover a very short distance at a time.
This means it's very important to get a good start to our movement.
Think about a 100 metre race where the sprinters start off with fancy starting blocks and compare that to a marathon where the start doesn't really matter because it's such a long race.
This shows that as the distance of travel decreases, the importance of having a good start increases.
So in badminton, where we only ever travel a few metres at a time, you can imagine how important it is to get a good start.
Generating explosive acceleration in a millisecond is essential.
When you're only travelling a few metres, you can think of the split step like a spark that jump starts your movement.
Also, do you ever feel like you've struggled to change the direction on court?
A common problem I used to have was I struggled to get to the shuttle when I was caught off guard and forced to change direction.
If I was already moving in a certain direction and my opponent hit the shuttle elsewhere, I would be left stranded on the court.
As a fun side note, in the UK we like to call this getting taxi because you're left stranded like you're waiting for a taxi.
As you can imagine, this was before I knew about the split step.

When I finally started to include it, I noticed a huge difference because not only does the split step jump start your movement, giving you a explosive push, it also resets your momentum, allowing you to change direction quickly and easily.
So how does it work?
The splittep involves you widening and lowering your base at the same time.
Get into the neutral stance we learned in the last video, my feet are both slightly wider than shoulder width apart and my knees are bent.
From here, I split step and as a result drop into this position.
My right foot is still slightly ahead of my left, but my legs are wider apart and lower and that's all there is to it.
After the split step, I would immediately begin my movement to whichever corner I needed.
It's a very simple movement by itself, but it's very powerful.
Just like our neutral stance, we want to be on our toes.
If we split step but landed on the back of our feet, we'd end up flat footed and unable to take off powerfully.
Also, avoid being too bouncy with a splitstep.
Even though I told you to hop, I don't want to see you gain too much vertical height.
This is a waste of energy and time.
Instead, you should think of it as a hop downwards.
Your feet come briefly off the floor, but your body is moving downwards.
Why does such a simple movement have such a huge effect on our speed?
Well, you can think of your legs like a spring.
A good split step is like compressing the spring.
After being compressed, the spring violently accelerates back into position, just like how we want an explosive start from our base position.
You can try this yourself.
Start in the middle of the court in a static position and try to quickly move to a corner.
You'll notice that no matter what you do, it'll feel a little sluggish.
Now try again, but first do a split step and then begin moving to that corner.
If you do this right, it should feel like magic.
It's a really Nifty hack that has a huge effect on acceleration.
In order for this to work, you need to move immediately after the split step.
If you pause even just for a second, then all the benefits are lost.
Because of this, the timing of a split step is very important.

You want to begin the split step just as your opponent is hitting the shuttle, so by the time that you land, you should already know which direction the shuttle is moving to, so you can split step and instantly travel to that corner without any delay.
The split step is also beneficial for changing direction.
Imagine you play a shot from the back of the court.
Obviously, you'll need to recover back to the middle so your momentum will be travelling forwards.
If your opponent notices this, they can take advantage by playing another lift to catch you off guard.
Even though it's the same corner you already came from, it can be quite difficult to change direction because you're already travelling forwards.
Here is a good demonstration of this.
My opponent anticipates a shot@the.net, so begins travelling forwards.
Since his body momentum is going this way, I decided to play a lift with a bit of deception.
It catches him off guard and he gets completely stuck and unable to change direction.
Now that's what I call a taxi.
Using a split step is a good way of preventing this from happening to you when you're recovering.
As your opponent is about to hit the shot, stop what you're doing and split step.
This resets your momentum, putting you in a good position to change direction if necessary.

I mentioned earlier that you want to split step with your right foot slightly ahead of your left foot, just like in the neutral stance that's because this is a great starting point that allows us to move to any corner.
Since we usually don't know what shot our opponent is going to play, this is useful as a general split step that we can use no matter where the shuttle goes.
However, there are some situations where we can anticipate what shot our opponent is going to play.
Maybe they have a predictable playstyle or they're under pressure and forced to play a certain shot.
In these situations, there are adapted variants of the split step that we can use.
That's why you see players split stepping with their right foot back or with their legs in a fronttoback formation at the neck.
Of course, the downside with this approach is that you're committing to move to a certain corner.
If you're wrong with your anticipation, it becomes much harder to move to the other corners of the court and get to the shuttle in time.
I don't want you to worry about these variations for now, we'll dig deeper into them in module three.

lessons.name: Running and Chasse Steps
lessons.description: Building block 3 and 4. Running steps and chasse steps are both ways of travelling around the court. They both have unique pros and cons, so a skilled badminton player must be able to select the correct option based on the situation.

sentences.text: So far, we've covered the first two building blocks of footwork, the stance and the split step.
In this video, we're going to build on that by learning how to actually move around a court.
In general, there are two ways you'll see players move.
They'll use either running steps or chassis steps.
These are both the correct and have their own pros and cons.
A good Balmont and player will be able to switch between them depending on the situation of the rally.
In this lesson, I'm going to teach you how to do both and how to choose between them depending on the situation.
First running Steps as the name suggests, running steps are very similar to how you're already used to moving.
It's simply the process of putting 1ft in front of another.
There isn't much to teach here since you already know how to do this, but it's worth noting that we're normally only used to running forwards.
In badminton, we have to run forwards, backwards and even diagonally.
Just like how running is the fastest way to complete a race, running steps in badminton are the fastest way to travel a long distance.

For example, if you needed to move from one corner of the court to another, you would use running steps, especially if you're travelling across the long diagonal, since this is the furthest distance on abandoned court.
However, there are two main issues with running steps.
Firstly, it's difficult to change direction.
Think about it, when you're running in a race, you only ever travel in one direction.
If you had to quickly change direction and move sideways, for example, that would be very difficult.
Secondly, running steps are only fast if you're travelling a long distance.
They're horribly inefficient for travelling short distances.
Imagine trying to move from here to here with running steps.
No matter how you do it, you can see that it doesn't work well.
The other type of movement we use are called chassis steps.
A chassis step is a movement where you step out with 1ft and then bring the other foot towards it in the same direction.
The crucial difference here is that your 2ft never cross over each other.
They can meet, but as soon as they do, the leading foot moves away again.
You may have noticed that fencers often use the chassis step.
Watch this athlete's feet as he moves forwards and backwards with chassis steps.
The reason fencers use this is the same reason badminton players use it.
The chassis step is incredibly quick and agile, allowing the user to quickly change direction.
Essentially, chassis steps are an alternate way of moving that addresses some of the downsides of running steps.
The chassis step is much more efficient for covering a short distance, but it's also adjustable.
I can adjust the distance of my feet in the chassis step, so if I have a very short distance to travel, they can stay further apart.
If I needed to travel a further distance I can bring my feet closer together to cover more ground.
It also allows you to move in a balanced and stable position, which is useful for jumping out to a corner or changing direction to chassis step.
Start by bringing your racquet foot in the direction you want to travel and then quickly follow with the other foot.
Repeat this movement as many times as necessary.
Notice how I'm on my toes for the entire movement.
This is what allows me to be fast and nimble.
If I didn't do this, I'd be flat footed.
It would look something like this and my footwork would be a lot slower.
You should be comfortable chassis stepping in any direction.
This means forwards, backwards or diagonally.
To do this, make sure your legs are lined up in the direction you want to travel.
When I travel forwards, my feet are lined up forwards.
When I travel sideways, they're lined up sideways.
When I travel diagonally, you guessed it, they're lined up diagonally.
In general, if we're travelling to the shuttle, we want to chassis with our racket leg leading.
And if we're recovering from the shuttle, we want to chassis with our non racket leg leading.
When you use chassis steps, make sure to keep your centre of gravity low and focus on horizontal movement.
It's a common mistake to be too bouncy.
A lot of players move up and down as the chassis step.
You want to avoid this.
Not only is it a waste of energy, it's also going to make you slower.

The chassis step isn't as intuitive as the running step since you don't use it in day to day life unless you're weird and chassis step around your kitchen, but it is still pretty simple and I found that my students tend to pick it up without too much issue.
Let's recap running and chassis steps here.
Lee Chong Wei is moving around the court with running steps.
As you can see, he's simply putting one leg in front of the other like you would if you were running.
He's doing this because he's moving from one corner of the court to another.
This is a long and straight distance to travel, so running steps are the most appropriate.
Here he is using chassis steps to travel to the rear corner.
Notice the key points he's leading with his right foot and then moves his left foot without them crossing over.
When he does this, he's maintaining a low centre of gravity.
Look at his feet.
Notice that he is travelling on his toes, which is what allows him to be so quick.
The reason he's using chassis steps is because he's only travelling a short distance from the middle to one of the corners.
And here's the slow motion breakdown of the chassis step.
Like I said, it's quite a simple movement.
When you practise, make sure to implement all the key points like I'm doing here and you'll be golden.
It's really important that you learn how to correctly use running steps and chassis steps before you move on.
This is something we constantly use in our footwork, so I'm going to be mentioning it again and again throughout this course.
So from this point on, I'm going to assume you've passed the checklist and can perform both movements comfortably.
Your assignment for this video is to master the chassis step.
Spend some time implementing the techniques you learned in this video until you feel comfortable with the movement.
Then I want you to stand in the middle of the court and practise chassis stepping from side to side.
This drill looks incredibly easy, but the goal for all the assignments is technical mastery and fluency.
Don't just go through the motions.
I want you to keep in mind the key points I mentioned like a low centre of gravity and staying on your toes.
This drill isn't designed to challenge you.
It's just to develop good motor patterns since we're still in the earlier stages of the course.
With this in mind, start off in the middle of the court and chassis from side to side.
Repeat this for ten repetitions and also take a video recording for later.
Next we're going to practise chassis steps for the rear court.
This is the movement pattern responsible for unleashing many devastating jump smashes.
Stand in the middle of the court with your racket foot behind your non racket foot.
If you do this correctly, you should essentially be facing to the side from this position, chassis to the back of the court, leading with your racket leg.
Then from here chassis back to the middle, leading with your non racket foot.
Repeat this ten times and record yourself.
The last exercise we're going to do is at the front of the court.
This will help you develop a more threatening net game by improving your front court movement.

Again, start off in the middle of the court, but this time stand with your racket foot forwards so you're facing the opposite side chassis to the front of the court with your right foot leading, and then chassis back with your left foot leading.
As you guessed, I want you to repeat this ten times and record yourself now, even though only ten reps are mandatory, please don't be afraid to do more.
In fact, I highly recommend that you spend as much time as necessary to get comfortable with the movement.
For some of you, that might only be ten reps, but others may require a bit more work.
So feel free to take as much time as you need.
And remember, this applies to all assignments in the course.
I don't want you to move on until you feel ready and that the movement has become muscle memory.
Once you've recorded these movements, open up this lesson Swift checklist.
Assess your own technique by following instructions and move on if you get the thumbs up.
This assignment is longer than the other ones we've done so far and that's just because the stance and splits step are very simple movements.
As you progress with this course the assignments are going to start to recover more work.
Starting with this lesson.
This extra work shouldn't put you off.
So many people come to me and ask for one to one coaching but Unfortunately I have to turn them all down due to the demands from Swift badminton school.

But with these assignments and the Swift checklist I'm giving you the opportunity to get personalised feedback and advice from me so don't skip out on these just because they're difficult or you'll miss out on a valuable learning experience.

We've now covered four of the eight building blocks so you should have a good idea on how to prepare and start your movement in the next few lessons we're going to cover the other half which are all different ways of finishing your movement.
I'll see you there.
Bye.

lessons.name: Lunge
lessons.description: Building block number 5. The lunge is a large, final step used to cover extra distance - commonly used at the front of the court. Be sure to complete the assignments in below.

sentences.text: We've covered the stance and split step, which are how to position yourself before moving.
Then we learnt running steps and chassis steps, which are how you actually move to the shuttle.
The last four building blocks are finishing moves.
No, not the types of finishing moves you'll see in Mortal Kombat.
You move in badminton is the way that you move as you hit the shuttle, thereby finishing the movement pattern.
In this video, we'll be covering the lunge, a big final step to get to the shuttle commonly used at the front of the court.
Lunging like this isn't exclusive to badminton.
Again, I want to show you a clip of fences.
I don't even follow the sport, but I find their movement to be mesmerising.
Notice how the fencer closes the distance between him and the opponent with a well timed lunge.
This is actually very similar to how we use in badminton, for example.
When moving to the net, we can cover the final part of the movement with a lunge.
This is a highly efficient movement and gives us a stable base to hit the shuttle from.
Watch how natural this movement looks for a shot@the.net.
And now compare that to if I tried to do this without a lunge.
Huge difference, right?
This works for a few reasons.
By taking a final large step, it maximises our reach.
It's also a very stable position to hit the shuttle from and allows us to recover easily by pushing off our front leg.
So let's have a look at how it's done.
We always lunge with our racket leg, so for most of us, this will be our right leg.
Take one large step with your right leg so you finish the movement with your foot well away from your body.
With the lunging knee bent, make sure your toe is pointing in the same direction as you're lunging.
