When most people lunge, they tend to have their back foot facing forwards as well, but you actually want to turn it 90 degrees so it's perpendicular to the direction that you are lunging.
So, as you can see, when I lunge forwards, the back foot is turned sideways.
The reason we do this is because the back foot acts as a brake to keep us stable in the lunge.
You might notice a distinctive Mark develop on the inside of your left shoe.
This is nothing to worry about.
In fact, it's actually a good thing.
Notice that I'm utilising my non racket arm when I lunge.
Even though it isn't hitting the shuttle, my left arm is still an important part of being balanced, so make sure it's out behind you.
This helps a lot with stability.
After you lunge and play your shop, you need to recover in preparation for the next shot.
Since you'll be leaning onto your racket leg, it's very simple.
All you have to do is push back against this leg and it will reset you back into a standing position so it will look something like this.
I lunge and hit the shuttle.
Then I recover by pushing off this leg.
You'll need to adjust your lunge based on the situation in the rally.
If you're not under a lot of pressure, your lunge will look a lot like what I've just showed you.
However, there will be times where you are under a lot of pressure.
If I'm late to the shuttle, I need to take a deeper lunge to get there, which would look something like this.
I've adjusted my lungs to reach a further distance.
There may be a temptation to bend your waist to get that extra distance, but this isn't ideal.
You do get to reach a little further, which might help you get to the shuttle, but it's a difficult position to recover from and compromises your balance.
And while there might be times where you're desperate and forced to bend at the waist, you want to prioritise lunging deep and low where possible.
As you can see, when I'm down here, I can reach a lot further with my lunge.
Here's a comparison of a regular lunge versus a deep low lunge.
Look how much more distance I can cover.
If I tried to lunge further without bending forward, it would look something like this.
Notice that I can't lunge as far and I'm also put in a bad position where my knee isn't stable.
To lunge low correctly requires strong legs.
At first, your legs might get very tired, but it's still worth doing because this is the most effective way of reaching the shuttle.
There's one more thing to note when lunging is low.
I mentioned earlier that you can recover from a lunge by pushing off the front leg, but when you're this low down, it becomes very difficult.
If I recovered by only trying to push off my front leg, you can see that it's very slow.
So in these situations, recover by simultaneously bringing your back foot inwards.
It will look something like this in real time.
This technique allows us to recover efficiently even when we're forced into a deep lunge.
Since the lunge is a finishing move, meaning it's used as we hit the shuttle, we can't just focus on the legs.
Remember, it's not just about moving to the shuttle, it's about hitting the shuttle.
So let's have a look at the upper body.
I've already mentioned that you want to keep your torso upright as you lunge, but now let's also focus on what the racket is doing.
There's a few points to keep in mind.
As soon as I start my lungs, I bring my racket forward in preparation to hit the shuttle.
This happens at the very start of the movement.
This is what it would look like if I didn't do this immediately.
Not only does this look pretty weird, can you see how it defeats the whole purpose of the lunge?
We want to get to the shuttle as soon as possible, since this gives us the most aggressive option.
But remember, the point of footwork isn't to get our body to the shuttle.
It's to get our racket to the shuttle.
So as you lunge, I want you to bring your racket to the shuttle as soon as you start moving forwards.
For the same reason you want to time your shop with your lunge.
To explain what this means, take a look at these three clips.
Which one looks correct to you?
Hopefully you chose the second option.
Why is this the correct one?
Well, in this case, I time my shot correctly with my lunge.
You can see that I'm contacting the shuttle at the same time as I land my foot.
This is the most efficient way to play the shot.
If I play the shot before I lunge, I don't have a stable position to hit from, and my recovery is compromised.
If I hit the shot well after my lunch, I get into the shuttle too early and I lose my sense of rhythm.
As usual, here is Lee Jongwe performing a lunge.
The first clip is him playing a normal lunge.
Can you spot the key points I brought up in this video?
And here is a clip of him lunging in a situation where he's under a lot of pressure.
Watch how he's able to lunge so much further by getting low and bending his legs.
Since he's in such a low position, he recovers by first dragging his back leg inwards to get into a better position.
In this case, he actually collapses quite a lot of the torso.
This is acceptable in situations where you literally need to do anything you can just to stay in the rally, but it still isn't ideal.
Only consider bending at the torso if your legs are already at maximum range.
There were a lot of technical points to take in this video, so I'm going to recap all of the key points in a list.
Bring your racket up and get it in position.
As soon as you start the lunge, land heel toe by pointing your toe upwards.
As you step through the lunge, make sure your front foot is pointed in the same direction that you're lunging in.
Hold your left hand behind you for balance.
Turn your non racket foot sideways.
It should be 90 degrees in order to act as a break.
Keep the upper body upright and get low by bending your legs.
Recover from the lunge by pushing off against your front leg.
If you're in a deep lunge, you can help yourself recover by bringing the back leg inwards and here I am doing the lunge in slow motion.
Do you see how I'm implementing all of the key points into my lunge?
Make sure you do the same when you attempt it yourself.
Your assignment for this lesson is to master the lunge.
There was a lot to learn in this video, so take the time to make sure you understand everything correctly.
Then it's time to try it yourself.
First, spend some time getting a feel for it.
Don't use a shuttle.
Just stand with your racket and shadow the lunge.
Don't rush this part and make sure you're implementing all of the key points correctly.
The next part of the assignment is to add in the shuttle.
Position yourself near the front of the net.
You should be just a bit behind the front service line like I am here.
Stand with your feet side by side.
Get a feeder to throw a shuttle under arm over the net without taking any steps.
Lunge from here and hit the shuttle then recover back to the standing position by pushing off your front leg.
Do this for ten reps.
If you only have one shuttle, just play a net shot and have your feeder reuse that shuttle.
The feeder needs to be feeding the shuttle slowly giving the worker enough time to recover between each shot.
If the worker starts to struggle, the feeder needs to slow down.
Don't worry too much about the quality of the shots here.
The focus is just on how you move for the same reason.
If you can't find someone to feed you, that's okay.
I would really try to find someone to help you but if you can't just shadow the movement.
Shadowing just means doing the same movement but without a shuttle.
Either way, make sure you record it and run it through the checklist.
If you pass Congratulations.
The lunge is a movement we're going to use continuously in our game and it's critical for fast front court play.
If you don't pass the Swift checklist, make sure you take the feedback on board and use it to correct your lungs.
When you start implementing the lunging, you'll see a huge improvement with your front court retrieval skills.
In the next video, we'll cover another finishing move but this time at the back of the court.
Stay tuned.

lessons.name: Scissor Kick
lessons.description: The 6th building block. The scissor kick is used at the back of the court when playing overhead shots. It allows the player to generate extra momentum and sets up for an aggressive recovery.

sentences.text: Now who doesn't like winning rallies with a wellplaced smash?
I know I do, and apparently so does all of YouTube.
The 6th building block isn't just going to help us generate more power in our smashes, it's also going to allow you to follow up quicker so you can get to the net and play that kit.
In this lesson we'll be learning about the scissor kick.
The scissor kick is a finishing movement that we use at the back of the court as we hit an overhead shot.
It's called a scissor kick because our legs change position from front to back like a pair of scissors.
I know it's not a very good analogy, but no one else came up with anything better.
The scissor kick is only used at the back of the court.
Obviously, this isn't something that we use at the front that would look pretty ridiculous when we hit an overhead shot in badminton.
We typically start off with our racket leg backwards and our non racket leg forwards.
The scissor kick involves turning your body in mid air so you land with your racket leg forwards and your non racket leg backwards.
There are two main benefits to this technique.
Number one is everyone's favourite, especially if you're the type of person who likes to smash everything.
It allows us to generate more power in our shots because we're putting the weight of our body into the shot.
Look at the right side of my body, the same side where my racket is.
As I rotate, you see that I'm generating a lot of momentum and this gets transferred into the shuttle.
You can think of this like throwing a ball from a sitting position versus being able to put the weight of your body into the throw.
Which one do you think would go further?
The other benefit is that it allows you to follow up your shot with aggressive movement.
After you hit a shot at the back of the court, especially if it's a straight smash, you want to start moving forwards as quickly as possible.
The faster you can get there, the more pressure you'll be able to exert and you may even get there in time to play a net kill.
With this as a kick, you're already starting the forward's momentum as you hit the shuttle.
You're also landing in a way that allows you to quickly push off the back leg like a spring.
This essentially gives us a head start, which allows us to move forwards with a lot more speed.
So let's have a look how it's done.
Start with your racket leg behind, your non racket leg a little wider than shoulder width apart.
This is the position you should get most of your overhead shots from the scissor kick jump and rotate your feet at the same time.
When I say jump, I don't mean you need to get a lot of vertical height.
All you have to do is get both feet off the floor just long enough for them to switch position.
At the same time, you would swing your racket at the shuttle.
When you land, you want to be in this position.
My racket foot is now at the front and it's pointing forwards.
My non racket foot is now at the back and it's pointing sideways.
This is incredibly important.
Make sure your back foot is pointing this way when you land.
This is the safest way to land.
If you tried to land with this foot pointed forward, you'd put a lot of strain on your Achilles tendon and this could lead to an injury.
So land with your foot sideways and this also leads nicely to my next point.
When you land from the scissor kick or any shot.
Really, you want to start recovering as soon as possible.
In the case of a rear court shot, this means moving forwards, and if you played a smash, it's especially important that you start moving forwards fast.
As I mentioned, the fact that our momentum is already moving forward is a good start, but we can do even better by pushing off the back leg.
When you scissor kick, your back foot will usually land slightly before your front foot.
As soon as it meets the floor, you want to push against the ground to propel yourself forwards.
Think of it like a sprinter pushing against the starting blocks to launch himself forwards.
Generally, when you seize a kick, both feet need to come off the floor.
This is the most aggressive movement and allows us to switch our feet in mid air.
But while we are jumping, this is not the same thing as a jump smash.
In the jump smash, the goal is to jump as high as possible to get a steeper angle on the smash.
This is an advanced technique that really shouldn't be attempted until you get to a much higher skill level.
I know it's tempting, but learning the jump smash really won't be useful right now.
The scissor kick is something different.
It's a fundamental movement that every balanced player needs to learn and do regardless of ability.
Don't get this confused with the jump smash just because you are jumping in the air.
But now in the scissor kick, I only want you to jump the minimum amount required to switch your feet around and rotate your body.
Trying to jump any higher is just going to mess with your timing and consistency.
The scissor kick is an aggressive movement, so in general, it's only used when you have time to get behind the shuttle.
Getting your body behind the shuttle is a very good position to hit from.
If you are under pressure, that means you wouldn't have as much time to get to the shuttle.
So maybe taking it from behind your body.
In this situation, the scissor kick is generally not a good idea.
Like you see here.
Trying to scissors in this position looks a little silly.
I'm not getting any of the benefits because the shuttle was already gone well past my body.
A more defensive finishing move would be more appropriate here.
Because of this, you'll see the scissor kick being used frequently in doubles.
Think about it.
If you're smashing in doubles, you only need to worry about the back half of the court.
Since your partner is at the front, you always have time to get behind the shuttle.
The scissor kick is great here since you're not under pressure, so it allows you to generate extra power.
But when you play singles, you'll commonly find yourself under movement pressure because you have to cover the entire court on your own and your opponent will be trying to move you around.
For this reason, physical kicks are seen less than singles.
Save it for when you have the upper hand and have time to get behind the shuttle.
The one exception to this is that you still generally see the kick when the shuttle has gone slightly behind you on the backhand side.
If the shuttle's only gone slightly past you, it sometimes still makes sense to do this as opposed to playing a backhand shot.
We'll discuss that a bit more in depth in Module Three.
There are two main differences when playing a shot like this.
Firstly, your body will actually be moving backwards as you hit the shot.
So while you're still generating momentum in the scissor kick with body rotation, your body as a whole will be travelling backwards.
When this happens, you also often see the player change the position of their feet without a jump, instead opting to bring their non racket leg backwards instead.
You'll also see this if a player is trying to conserve energy, don't worry about these variations for the scissor kick.
For now, we'll cover them in more detail when we go over the backhand corner in Module Three.
And when you learn the standard scissor kick I first showed you, it becomes much easier to adapt it to different variations.
Again, I just want to let you know that these exist so you don't get confused if you watch a band player do something different.
To recap, here's Lee Chongwe demonstrating a scissor kick.
He first plays a drop shot with a scissor kick and then does the same thing for a smash.
Let's have a look at how he demonstrates the key points from this video.
He starts off with his right foot back and his left foot forwards.
As he hits the shuttle, both feet come off the floor.
He switches the position of his feet in midair and in doing so generates forwards momentum to his hips.
He first lands with his back foot and quickly follows up with the front foot.
Notice that the back foot is pointed sideways while the front foot is pointed forwards.
He then pushes off the back foot to propel himself forward for his recovery.
This is even more visible when he smashes since he needs to get forwards quickly and here I am performing a scissor kick in slow motion.
You should notice all the key points here as well so this is a very useful video for you to copy and analyse.
Until now, the previous videos have covered pretty simple concepts.
From this point onwards we'll be getting more advanced so these slow motion clips will be a useful resource.
Rewatch this as many times as you need and try to copy my movement especially for the assignments.
Your assignment for this video is to master the scissor kick first.
Take some time to go through everything you learn and spend some time practising it on your own.
Take as much time as you need here and go through all the key points until you feel comfortable with them.
Once you are it's time to get on court stand near the back of the court in this position racket foot backwards non racket foot forwards.
My body is essentially facing sideways from here.
Have a feeder hit a shot to you.
You're going to hit the shot whilst scissor kicking and then do the first few steps of the recovery.
Focus on pushing off the back foot.
The quality of the actual shot you play doesn't really matter but I recommend that you play clear since it's the easiest.
Repeat this ten times and make sure you record it since we're going to run it through the Swift checklist.
If you don't have a feeder I would really recommend that you try to find one but if you really can't that's okay too.

lessons.name: China Jump
lessons.description: The 7th building block. The China jump is also used at the back of the court for overhead shots. Though it isn't as powerful as the scissor kick due to the lack of body rotation, it's a more versatile option.

sentences.text: The China Jump is the penultimate building block.
It's also a reocort finishing move.
Just like this is a kick, it allows us to play aggressive options.
However, the China Jump can still be used when we don't have time to fully get behind the shuttle.
Because of this, you'll see it frequently used in single, especially on the forehand side.
Like I said in the last video, in singles you'll often be under movement pressure, which makes it harder to use the scissor kick.
The China Jump is less powerful, but for those reasons, it's a pretty good trade off for singles.
The key difference compared to a scissor kick is that we don't rotate our legs.
When I jump out, my racket leg is at the back, and it stays this way throughout the entire movement.
As you can tell, there's much less body rotation compared to the scissor kick, so there's less power.
The China Jump is also great for jumping out to the mid court and intercepting a flat lift.

This is another great aggressive option that allows you to counterattack instead of being forced to play a weak shot like a backhand, you start the chime jump in the same position as the scissor Kick.
Let's look at the forehand side first.
Your racket leg should be behind your non racket leg.
They should be lined up in the direction that you're moving.
In this case, I'm jumping out straight to the back of the court, so my feet are lined up in a front to back position.
Aim to land with both feet at the same time, but there will be times when your back foot lands first, and that's okay.
As soon as you land, you need to push off the back foot to propel yourself forwards in the recovery.
Just like this is a kick, your back foot needs to be turned sideways and you push off the middle part of the foot.
It's a little different on the backhand side.
Unlike most movements where the forehand and backhand side are quite similar for the China Jump, they're actually used for very different purposes, and we'll get more into that in Module three.
But just keep that in mind as I show you the technique for the backhand China Jump.
This time, stand with your non racket foot behind your racket foot.
Again, line them both up in the direction you want to travel.
In this case, I'm jumping out diagonally, so my feet are also lined up diagonally.
From here, you want to jump out to the corner and hit the shuttle.
Try to jump by pushing off with both feet, but it's only natural that you will use more of the back foot in the takeoff.
Then make sure you recover quickly by pushing off the back foot.
Recovering is just like on the forehand side.
Make sure your back foot is pointed sideways and start pushing off it as soon as you land.
As an interesting side note, this is the only time we hit an overhead shot in badminton with our non racket foot backwards.
Typically, we have our racket foot backwards.
The reason the China Jump looks so different on the backhand side is because it's harder to reach the shuttle.
I have to bring my racket around my head to do so compared to the forehand side, which is a lot more natural because my racket is already in position.
As you can see, this requires quite a bit of flexibility as you bend around to get that extra reach.
Because of this, the China Jump is used less on the backhand side and more on the forehand side.
Since you'll often be using the China Jump when the shuttle has gone behind you, a lot of the time you'll be jumping backwards.
The China Jump is a highly adjustable movement pattern.
Sometimes you'll be jumping up very high, sometimes your feet will barely leave the ground.
Sometimes you'll be travelling backwards, sometimes you'll be moving more to the side.
This is part of the reason you'll see it so much in singles.

lessons.name: Net Jump
lessons.description: The final building block. The net jump is used to pounce on a loose shot at the net. High risk, high reward.

sentences.text: The final building block is a little more obscure.
You won't get the chance to use it often in badminton, but I still call it a building block because it's one of the most effective ways of winning points.
And even though it's quite simple, it's actually a fairly unique movement, so you need to dedicate some time to learning it.
I'm talking about the next jump, which is used for playing kills.
You can think of it like pouncing onto the shuttle@the.net.
Net jumps are the fastest way of getting to the shuttle, since you're literally committing everything and leaping to it.
However, it also puts you in a position that's impossible to recover from.
If I jump in like this and the neck shot goes to the back of the court, there is practically no way for me to get back there in time.
So the only time you should use the net jump is when you're in a position to end the rally.
If you ever have the opportunity to play a kill, you should always take it.
A kill is the most effective shot, and it's the best way of ending a rally, but you only have a limited window of time to play the kill.
Once the shuttle drops below the tape, it's gone.
The net jump is used to get to the shuttle while we can still kill it.
The movement itself is actually pretty intuitive.
Start off with your racket leg forwards.
When you're at the net, this will generally be the stance that you're in, and we'll talk a bit more about that in module three.
From this stance, as soon as you notice the shuttle is coming over the net high enough to kill, you need to decide if you're going to commit to the net jump or not.
If so, reach out with your racket and jump towards it.
You should take off and land with your racket leg.

Keep your non racket arm behind.

It's literally just a leap towards the net.

If you're going to use the net jump, you have to commit to it 100%.

Just lunge in and play a safe shot.
The reason for this is if you're on the fence about the net jump, you get the worst of both worlds.
You won't have the decisiveness to end the rally, but you'll still put yourself in a position that's impossible to recover from.
When you go for a net jump, I want you to be thinking this exact statement in your head.
I'm going to win the rally outright.
I do not care what happens after this shot.

He leaps forwards primarily pushing off his right foot and also landing on it.

Your assignment is to learn how to do this.

lessons.name: Forehand Rear Court
lessons.description: The forehand rear corner is a critically important corner in badminton. In this lesson you’ll learn more about the scissor kick, China jump and step out to this corner. As well as the “secret” that allows you to move to this corner with more efficiency.

sentences.text: The forehand rear corner is critical.
In badminton, not only are you going to be moving to this corner a lot, the ability to play high quality shots from here is going to be key in controlling the pace of rallies.
In order to play quality shots, you need to get to the shuttle in time.
In an ideal world, we'd have time to get to every shuttle early, but this isn't realistic since it's our opponent's only goal to put us under pressure.
That's why players who have good footwork in this area have such a huge advantage.
In this lesson, I'm going to teach you everything you need to know about moving to the forehand rear corner.
We'll go over the three movement options, how to choose between them, the best ways to recover, and a small adjustment that increases the efficiency of moving to this corner.
Let's start off with an overview of the three options.
First, we have the Scissor Kick.
This is the most aggressive option since it allows us to put our body weight into the shop.
However, it requires us to be behind the shuttle, which we don't always have the time for, especially in singles.
Next, we have the China Jump.
This is a more flexible option that still allows us to play a quality shot even if we're late to the shuttle.
Because of this, the China Jump is the most used option in singles.
Obviously, the downside is you still can't generate as much power doing this compared to the Scissor Kick.
The last option is the step out.
This is used when we're under a lot of pressure and very late to the shuttle.
Obviously, moving in this way isn't ideal, so it's safe for defensive situations, but getting this right will allow you to escape from many difficult situations which could save you the rally.

There are a few variations on this depending on the exact position of the shuttle and how late we are, but for our purposes, we'll characterise the fundamental movement as defensive footwork with a crossover of the legs and a lunge into the corner.
Let's have a look at these in detail, but remember, you need to have learned the building blocks in order to do this correctly.
First, the Scissor Kick start off in the middle of the court with your neutral stance.
This means my feet are a bit wider than shoulder width apart with my right leg slightly in front.
From here, I do a quick split step.
I then need to bring my right foot backwards slightly so my body is now angled towards the forehand corner.
This puts me in a good position, so when I chassis, I'll be going in the right direction.
I take two shallow steps to get behind the shuttle and then Scissor Kick.
As soon as I scissor, I begin recovering by pushing forwards from my back leg.
So one more time split step, bring my right leg back, take two chassis steps, then Scissor kick and hit.
This should be super simple if you've learned the building blocks, since it's just about chaining them together.
Like I said, this is the most aggressive option since we're utilising the Scissor kick.
But in order for the scissor kick to work, we need to be well behind the shuttle.
Depending on the exact position of the shuttle, you might need to take one or two chassis steps.
I mentioned two in the demonstration, but the amount doesn't matter.
Just get behind the shuttle.
Next we'll take a look at the China jump.
Just like before, we start off in the neutral stance.
After a quick split step, we then bring our right leg back just like before.
From here we only take one chassis step and then China jump towards the shuttle.
We can then recover back towards the middle by pushing forwards against the back foot.
We use this in situations where we don't have the luxury of getting behind the shuttle.
So we only take one chassis step and then cover the rest of the distance with a China jump.
This is much quicker, so it allows us to play quality shots even if we're a little late to the shuttle.
Another great thing about the China jump is that it can be varied a lot.
Sometimes you'll only be taking a small hop where your feet barely leave the floor to conserve energy.
Sometimes you'll be travelling backwards quite a lot as you hit.
If you need to cover a lot of distance quickly and sometimes you'll be jumping up high to meet the shuttle in order to play more aggressively.
Right now you only need to focus on the standard China jump and later on you'll be able to adapt it.
The beauty of the China jump is that it can be adapted to so many different situations.
On the forehand side, we went over the scissor kick and China Jump fairly briefly since they're basically just a combination of the building blocks that you should already have learned.
You should be able to chain these movements together quite easily.
But the final option, the step out, is a little different.
Remember, the step out is a movement that we use when we're under a lot of pressure on the forehand side.
This is how you do it from your neutral stance.
Do a split step, then take your left leg and bring it behind your right leg.
From here you can reach the corner with one large lunge to the forehand corner with your right leg and hit the shuttle from this position.
Then recover by pushing off your lunging leg one more time.
That split step left leg behind the right leg, then lunge and hit with the right leg.
This is what you want to do when you're under a lot of pressure.
Specifically, you'll be taking the shuttle very low in this sort of an area.
The cross behind is a lot like running steps and it allows you to cover distance quickly.
Then, depending on how much pressure you're under, the lunge is a last ditch attempt to get to the shuttle.
This involves turning your body towards this corner and lunging as far as necessary.
Obviously, this is never ideal.
You can't play a powerful shot from here and it makes it quite difficult to recover, but it gives you a lot of extra reach.
So it could be the difference between losing the point and just being able to stay in the rally.
And that's why we use it again.
This is another footwork pattern with a lot of variation.
I taught you the fundamental movement, but in a real game, you adapt.
It based on how much pressure you're under.
If you're not under that much pressure, but you still need to step out, there are two things that you can change.
Instead of lunging, you can hit the shuttle from a more natural position like this.
Here, I'm still leaning into the shot and bending my knees to reach a lower shuttle, but because I don't need to lunge, this increases the quality of the shot and makes my recovery much easier.
Also, you can adjust how far you cross behind.
If you don't have as far to travel, this cross behind movement can be less pronounced and may start to look more like a chassis.
As usual, I just want to make you aware that these variations exist.
Stick to the Fundamental Not only is it the most important, you'll naturally start to be able to adapt it as you get more practise.
Now, we've covered all three movements.
Let's have a look at how you would recover from the forehand rear core.
It largely depends on the actual shot that you hit, regardless of whether you use the scissor kick, China jump, or step out.
Let's say I play an aggressive shot like a smash.
In this case, I have to recover much quicker.
This makes sense since there's less time for me to get ready, so I need to move with more urgency.
In contrast, if I play a high clear, I have more time to prepare for the next shot.
I know the shuffle is going to be in the air for longer, so I can move slower as long as I still recover to my base in time.
In fact, sometimes you can even walk back to your base position, but Ironically, this is actually a more advanced technique, so I wouldn't really worry about it for now.
So in general, for defensive or neutral situations, we use chassis steps to recover.
Using chassis steps makes sense here, since we're not travelling a long distance just from the forehand corner to the middle of the court.
Also, our opponents next shot could go to any corner after we play a neutral or defensive shot, so using chassis steps allows us to change direction if necessary.
In aggressive situations, you actually want to commit a lot harder after you play a good smash, you want to start moving forwards, anticipating a return to the net.
In this case, the recovery would use running steps, since we're covering a long distance very quickly from the back of the court all the way to the front.
Why does this work?
Well, when you smash, the most common response will be a block to the net.
Think about a time where you had to defend a powerful smash.
You probably just played a straight block because that was the only thing that you could do.
It's very hard to play a good lift or a cross court block if you're under a lot of pressure.
You can take advantage of this fact when you play a good smash, and by coming in early straightaway, it allows you to put more pressure on the block return.
Of course, this is a little risky.
If your opponent plays the shot anywhere else, it becomes harder to change direction and get there in time.
So you should decide how hard to commit by how much pressure your smash puts them under.
If they're struggling just to get it back, you can start moving forward quite quickly.
But if your smash doesn't put them under much pressure, be more cautious when moving in, since they could still play a lift or take you cross court.
If that was confusing, just remember it like this in most situations.
Recover by chassis stepping back to the middle.
But if you play a good smash and can anticipate a block return, start taking running steps forwards.
Whichever you choose, make sure to push off your back foot as soon as you land to propel yourself forwards.
So that's the recovery for the Scissor kick and China jump.
But for the step out, it's a little different when you're under extreme pressure.
The step out ends with a lunge out to the corner.
Recover by pushing back off from the lunging leg and transition this movement into forward momentum.
After recovering from the lunge, I can bring my right leg towards my left leg and this initiates the chassis movement.
I can get back to the middle of the court.
I mentioned that if you're not under too much pressure, you might not need to lunge.
In this case, you're in a very similar position to when you land a China jump.
So recover by pushing off the rear leg and taking chassis steps back to the middle.
Now we've covered the three options for moving to the forehand rear corner and the two recovery options from it.
Let's talk about the split step.
Until now, we've been mainly using the standard split step, with our feet roughly wider than shoulder width apart and our racket foot slightly in front of our non racket foot.
This split step is pretty good for getting us to all corners, which is why it's standard.
However, this isn't always the fastest way of moving to a specific corner.
For the forehand rear corner, there's a faster, more effective option.
This Altered Split Step works really well here, but it also works really badly for some other corners.
This makes it a bit of a double edged sword.
I have this one friend who I've been playing singles with for years, and at this point I pretty much know his gameplay.
In particular, he loves to do this one shot where he comes into the net and plays a flat cross court lift to my deep forehand corner.
It's gotten to the point where I can anticipate pretty well when he's going to do it.
When I do, I use the Altered Split Step.
Since this gets me to the forehand corner faster and allows me to counterattack, it's difficult to see exactly what I'm doing here.
So let me break it down.
In the Standard Split Step, my right foot is in front of my left foot.
The Auto Split Step just requires one small adjustment.
Keep your feet the same width, but split step with your right foot behind your left foot.
This way, your body is already angled towards the forehand corner.
It should make sense why this is faster.

When I showed you the footwork to this corner with the Standard Split Step earlier, the first thing I had to do was bring my racket foot backwards, and only then could I start chassising to that corner.
But if I use the Altered Split Step, I'm already in this position, so I can cut out the extra movement and begin moving immediately.

lessons.name: Smash Defense
lessons.description: With the front and rear court completel, the mid court is next. Defending smashes comes down to a split second. Learn the best way to move to increase your chance of staying in the rally.

sentences.text: To round off this module, we're going to look at the midcourt.
The midcourt is often overlooked, but skilled players are able to generate a lot of pressure from this area.
As usual, good footwork is key to doing this.
You'll be jumping out to intercept flat lifts, as well as straining loads to retrieve difficult smashes.
Now, before we get started, I want to emphasise that speed is incredibly important for these mid court shots.
Obviously, we always want to be quick when moving around at Bambin Court, but it's especially important to be explosive in the midcourt.
Both defending a smash and intercepting a shot come down to the split second, so even a small delay can result in you losing the rally for the next two lessons.
Technique is still incredibly important, but since these movements are a little simpler, you can focus a bit more on being snappy.
First, let's talk about smash defence.
The stance and split step are very important here.
Typically, we stand in the neutral stance, feet slightly wider than shoulder width apart, with the racket foot slightly ahead.
This is a good general base that allows us to move forward or backwards easily by pushing off a foot.
But we adapted slightly for smash defence.
If you expect that a smash is coming, you change this to a side by side stance with your feet in line with each other.
This does make it hard to move forward or backwards, since we no longer have a way to push off in these directions.
But this is excellent for defending a smash, since you're able to move side by side very effectively, which covers all smash options.
The other thing to note is that you need to get a lot lower than usual.
A good smash will come in fast and low, so starting in a lower position can be the difference between reaching the shuttle and missing it.
The best way to get low is to bring your feet wide apart.
Here, Lee Chong Wei splitstepping for a shot.
You can see he's obviously much wider than shoulder width and he's bending his knees to get down low.
It might feel a bit unnatural to get this low at first, but since it's so important for defending a smash, I need you to force yourself to do this.
Don't worry, it will soon become second nature.
This should get you in a position that looks like this.
Compare this to our neutral stance from earlier and you'll see that it looks very different.
Starting in this stance is much better for defending a smash, but you should only use it when appropriate.
This is for situations where you're confident that it smashes incoming.
For example, after you play a weaklift for most other situations, stick with the neutral stance.
Since we have very little time to react when defending a powerful smash, it's important to start off in the right position.
To begin with, you might think that our base is in the middle of the court, but this is not necessarily true.
Let's say your opponent is smashing from here.
He has the choice to do either a straight smash or a cross court smash.
It's important to note that a straight smash is much faster since it travels a shorter distance as a result.
This is the most threatening to you, so you should move your base slightly towards your opponent's straight smash.
If they smash from here where the straight smash would end up in my forehand corner, I would move slightly to the forehand side.
If they smash from here where the straight smash would go to my backhand corner, I would move slightly to the backhand corner.
Of course, if they're smashing from the middle, then your base position should be in the middle of the court.
For this lesson, let's first consider a situation where my opponent plays a straight smash.
This means I'll be standing close to the side that the smash comes from, so won't have to move as much first the forehand side.
If they're smashing from here, I'd move my base to this point of the court.
I prepare for the smash with a split step and after I see the smash coming in straight, I can defend the shot from the split step.
All I have to do is take a small step towards the shuttle, resembling a lunge to the side.
This movement should feel pretty natural, but the main concern isn't your feet the smash comes down so quickly.
The most important thing to do is to get your racket in position.
The very first thing that you should do when you see the smash incoming is to bring your racket out to the side even before you start moving.
This urgency is going to be especially important as you start to play against better and better players.
Accompany this with a small step and play the shot.
The exact distance to travel depends on where your base is and how far the smashes, but it should never be too far away from you.
If you've already biassed your base towards the straight smash, recover by pushing off the lunging leg and get back into position.
It's the same thing if your opponent is smashing straight from the backhand side of the court.
If the smash is coming from here, you need to move your base slightly to the left.
Again, this puts you in the best position to defend the straight smash.
Start off with a split step with the focus on getting low.
When you see the straight smash incoming, the first thing is to bring your racquet to the shuttle.
Accompany this by taking one step towards the corner lunging however far necessary to reach the shop.
Notice that I'm lunging with my left leg, which is unusual in Bamboaton.
We normally only want to lunge with our racket leg since this is a stronger position to be in.
But in this specific situation, defending a straight smash on the backhand side is one of the few times we lunch with the non racket leg.
Why?
Well, when defending a smash, and especially a straight smash, speed is the number one priority.
It's much quicker to take a small step with my left leg than it is to bring my right leg all the way around.
And since I've already biassed my base towards the left side, a small step with my left leg should be all it takes to get me in position.
The recovery is pretty simple.
Just push off the lunging leg and get back in position.
So as you can see for the forehand and backhand side, defending a straight smash is pretty straightforward.
Pun not intended.
If you're in the correct position, all you have to do is split step to get yourself low and then take one step with the nearest leg.
The main consideration is just to get your racquet in position as soon as possible, even if you move it before your legs.
So while this is pretty simple, what if your opponent decides to play a cross court smash?
Since we position ourselves as a straight smash, this gets a little more complicated.

This gives you the extra time needed to get into position.
Let's first have a look at a situation where I'm standing on my forehand side and they smash cross court to my backhand.

To recap.
