lessons.name: Interceptions
lessons.description: Pulling off a successful counter attack with an interception is one of the most satisfying things in badminton. Learn how to cut off your opponents flat lifts and change the pace of the rally.

sentences.text: Intercepting a shuttle is one of my absolute favourite things to do in badminton.

When your opponent plays a flat, clear lift with the intention of putting you under pressure, there's no better feeling than jumping out and punishing the attempt with a rally ending smash to round off your coverage of the entire court court.
You're going to learn how to do this in the mid court.
Trust me, you'll have a lot of fun pulling off a successful interception.
Before we get started, I wanted to point out that there is a bit of a crossover between a mid court interception and a China jump out to the rear court.
That's because it's a bit of a grey area.

The difference between a rear court shot and an interception really lies on a spectrum, but the focus of this lesson will be cutting off a flat shot before it reaches the back of the court, so there's a few key points to keep in mind.
Like I said in the last video on Smash defence, successfully playing a shot from the mid court requires a lot of speed and explosiveness.
You cannot hesitate if you want to successfully intercept the shuttle or it's just going to go flying past you and you're going to look silly.

Intercepting a shuttle isn't as much of a fundamental movement, meaning we're not going to use as much as the other footwork patterns we've learnt it's only suitable when your opponent plays a flat lift or clear, which is when the shuttle follows a low travel path.
Your opponent might try to play a shot like this to put you under pressure in the rear court, since a flat shot travels less distance and gets there quicker.
If successful, this can work quite well and force you into a defensive situation, like using the step out or backhand movement.
But if you're fast enough, you can turn the tables back on them by intercepting the shuttle in the middle of its flight path before it reaches the back of the court.
Instead of being put under pressure yourself, you'll be able to catch them off guard and play aggressively.
You can intercept a shot in the mid court on either the forehand or backhand side.
Either way, you'll be using a China jump.
First, let's look at the forehand side.
As usual, you start off in the middle of the court in a neutral stance.
As your opponent hits the shuttle, take a split step.
You should land just after he hits the shuttle and at this moment you need to decide if it's possible to intercept the shuttle.
If it isn't, just use one of the standard moving patterns we covered earlier.
But if it is possible, you've got to act quick.
The sooner you can get to the shuttle, the better your aggressive options will be.
Sometimes you'll intercept the shuttle while it's still in line with your body.
The movement here is very simple.
Just transition straight out of your split step into the interception.
It will look something like this split step then instantly trying to jump out.
This will have you jumping out into the side with your racket held upwards.
This allows you to play the shot before the shuttle travels past your body split step and instantly trying to jump out.
Timing is key here since you only have a split second to react.
Sometimes you might be a bit slower and the shuttle might have travelled slightly past you.
In these situations you can still intercept the shuttle if you're fast enough.
Let's say we're hitting the shuttle at around this point.
To do so I need to adjust my movement slightly.
The main difference is instead of jumping out to the side I need to jump out diagonally.
This allows me to get to the shuffle that's slightly behind me.
To do this I need to adjust my feet slightly after the split step.
Since I'm jumping out this way, I want my feet to be like this before I jump in line with the diagonal movement.
So I split step then adjust the position of my feet by taking a small step backwards with my right foot.
From here I instantly turn jump outward to intercept the shot.
So it's very similar to earlier.
All I need to do is adjust the movement to hit a shuttle that's gone slightly behind me.
You'll notice that the position my feet are in after this small step is the same position as the adjusted split step for the forehand rear corner.
This isn't a coincidence, it's a good way of moving towards the forehand corner.
In fact, it's just like before.
If you can anticipate this shot you can use the adjusted split step.
This is quicker because it allows you to transition instantly into the China jump without having to do this small step backwards first.
On the backhand side it's very similar.
You can intercept a flat shot by China jumping out to it instead of waiting for it to travel past you and being forced to play a weak backend reply.
Again.
We start off with a split step, then China jump out towards the shuttle.
I start off the split step with my left foot back and when I land the China jump it should stay this way.
This is the quickest way to reach a shot in this area.
It's actually simpler on the backhand side because you can use this movement.
No matter where the shuttle is.
There's no need to adjust your feet like on the forehand side.
All you have to do is China jump in the correct direction.
So if I'm reaching the shuttle earlier in its flight path I would China jump out to the side.
But if it's gone slightly further behind me my China jump would be more diagonal.
Just split step and China jump towards the shuttle.
The recovery for the forehand and backhand side is the same.
When you land the China jump, simply push off the back foot.
Like you learned in module two, this resets your position and allows you to get back to base.
That's really all there is to the footwork for an interception.
Like I said, it's a fairly technically simple movement, so we don't need to spend too much time on it.
It's simply a split step followed by an instant chime jump.
There isn't much technique to it.
A successful interception depends more on your ability to react quickly.
Every second you wait, the shuttle travels slightly further behind you and makes a successful interception more difficult.
Stay on your toes with the entire movement and focus on being snappy.
You don't have time to charge up a jump, so transition instantly from the splitstep into a China jump.
However, this is actually quite an advanced shot.
We've only talked about the footwork, which by itself is quite simple, but pulling this off in a real game is more complicated.
Not only is it something that requires a bit of practise, it also becomes much easier when you can anticipate the shot.
But again, that's something that comes with experience.
If you're a beginner and haven't developed that consistency in your standard overhead shots yet, this is going to be even harder due to the precise timing involved with an interception.
For this reason, it's fine to focus on the more basic movements.
For now.
Remember, you don't have to intercept the shot.
You can also play it from the rear court using one of the footwork patterns we learned earlier, and if you're a beginner, you might prefer to stick with that for now.
But for the more advanced players, you want to start practising and implementing this into your gameplay.
The interception will add an extra dimension, and it will allow you to catch your opponent off guard when you're under pressure by counterattacking.
Even though the movement itself is quite simple, we'll do a quick recap by watching Lee Chungwei.
Here, his opponent plays a flat lift to his backhand side, hoping to put Lichenwe under pressure in the rear court.
But Lee Chong Wei reacts quickly and is able to intercept the shot for a while.
It's still in the mid court.
He splits that as soon as the shot is hit, and when he lands, he realises that it's a shot he can intercept, so he instantly China jumps out to play the shot.
The shuttle has gone slightly behind him, so you'll notice he's moving diagonally out and back.
He then recovers from the China jump by pushing off his back leg, just like we learnt previously.
Here's an example.
On the forehand side, after defending a smash, his opponent plays a flat lift.
Lee Chong Wei reacts to this quickly and is able to try and jump out and intercept the shuttle while it's still in the mid core.
This is practically the exact same as the backhand side.
The only difference, of course, is the direction of the shot.
As usual, the slow motion will be included at the end of the video.
Your assignment is to practise the interception footwork.
Start off in the middle of the court and shadow this movement on the forehand side ten times.
Start with a split step and try to jump out.
You can try the different variations I mentioned, like when the shuttle is to the side or diagonally behind you.
You can also try it with the adjusted forehand split step.
Once you've done that, repeat it for ten shadows on the back hand side.
It's the same movement.
Split step and China jump out record both these movements and run them through the Swift checklist.
Even though it's a fairly basic technique, I still want to make sure that you're doing it correctly before you progress.
As an optional extra, you can get a feeder to Multifeed you these shots.
However, I'm not including it as a mandatory assignment because again, this is quite a difficult drill to feed accurately.
But if you're lucky enough to have a skilled feeder to help you out, I would recommend it since it gives you a good feeling of what it's like to intercept with an actual shuttle.
Work on the forehand and backhand side separately.
Each shot should be deliberately fed to make it as easy as possible for you to intercept.
This means it should be quite low and not very powerful.
A good shuttle path would look something like this.
I know what you're thinking.
That looks really easy and wouldn't happen in a real game, but that's actually the point.
The purpose of this drill is to help you build up the correct muscle memory and give you a feel for what it's like to intercept the shuttle.
This is much easier when you're fed shots that are easy to intercept so you can focus on what your feet are doing instead of struggling just to reach the shuttle.
Again, this is purely optional, so if you don't have a feeder, you'll be fine by just shadowing the movement.
The whole focus of Module Three has been to teach you the correct movements.
In the next module, we're going to kick things up a notch and you'll be pushed even harder.
This will allow you to develop more speed, but it's important that you can do all the techniques correctly before trying to increase the pace.
If you try to move on without being technically sound, it's going to look like a hot mess.
But with that being said, well done for making it to the end of Module Three.
There has been an absolute tonne of information given to you, so if you feel overwhelmed, don't worry.
That's completely normal.
I've given you ten years of footwork knowledge in a very short span of time.
I told you I was going to be thorough.
Make sure you take your time as you go through this module.
I can't stress how important that is.
This is how it went from being a clumsy mess on court to where I am now.
I'm really excited for you to reach all your footwork and balmatin goals.
Footwork is one of the most important things you can learn and once you apply everything in this module, you'll be light years ahead of the competition.
Instead of struggling to reach every shuttle, you'll be moving and playing at a much faster pace that will allow you to dominate your opponents.

lessons.name: The Importance of Drills
lessons.description: Congratulations and Welcome to the Footwork Fastlane! You're about to build your footwork from the ground up, and I'll be there to guide you every step of the way.

sentences.text: I want you to think back to the first time you played a certain video game.
Maybe it was a fighting game, a first person shooter, or a mobile.
And if you're not a gamer, I want you to just pretend for now, you didn't know what each button on the controller did, and you had to constantly refer back to the instruction manual.
Maybe you couldn't even do the basics like move your character around.
After spending some time playing the game, you learn what all the controls are and can do the basics, but you're still a little clumsy and have to consciously think about what buttons to press.
You would struggle to play the game if you were distracted, for example, trying to maintain a conversation with someone at the same time.
This is probably a good representation of where your footwork was when you started the course.
After going through module two and three, as well as doing all of the assignments, you should see a huge amount of progress.
You'll go from awkwardly stumbling around the court to being very fluent with your footwork.
Not only that, you should be able to do it without even thinking your legs will move as if they had a life of their own, but still execute all the techniques correctly with speed and precision.
You've heard me constantly say that you need to build the muscle memory before the speed, but at this point you should have the muscle memory down.
So, as promised, let's start building up the speed, and that's exactly what module four is going to be about.
Until now, you've had to focus on technique over speed, but from this point on it's going to be technique and speed.
We're going to take the fundamentals that you've already learned and push it further than you can imagine.
This is where your hard work pays off.
By the end of the module, not only will you be moving around, abandonement court with great fundamental footwork, you'll be doing so at a speed that you've previously thought was impossible.
As a side note, have you ever sat in a class and thought, Why are we learning this?
When are we ever going to use this information in real life?
Me too.

It's pretty frustrating, and while the assignments have been great for helping you build the correct muscle memory, and I certainly hope the course hasn't been boring, this module is going to revolve around taking the knowledge you've just learned and implementing it into a real game.
This will be especially useful if you're a balanced player who has pretty good skills and practise.

But as soon as you step on court and there's a shuttle involved, all those skills goes right out of your head and you're back to square one, this module will help you bridge the gap so you're just as sharp in game as you are in training.
We'll start off pretty simple, but we'll progress onto more advanced drills that even professional players frequently use in their footwork training.
This will cover a wide range of movements, all of which have the goal of developing a certain aspect of your footwork and implementing it into a real game.
For example, one drill might focus on increasing your speed in aggressive situations, while another might be based around improving your reaction time.
But before we get into it, I want to give you some more context.
All of the drills you're about to do can be placed in one of three categories shadow, multi feed, or live rally.
You should already be familiar with shadow.
Most of the assignments in the footwork fast Lane have some element of shadow in them.
It's simply any footwork drill that takes place without a shuttle.
For example, practising lunges on an empty court is a shadow exercise.
But there's also more advanced shadow drills that we're going to cover.
In this module, we've also done some multi feed drills.
This is when someone feeds you multiple shuttles at once.
It can be hand thrown or hit with a racket and involves you moving to the shuttle and playing a shot.
Then, instead of returning the shot, the feeder will hit over the next shuttle in his possession.
Lastly, we have live rallies, which you haven't seen much of until now.
This starts off the same as a multi feed.
The feeder hits you a shuttle for you to retrieve, but the drill continues for as long as you can keep the rally going with the one shuttle.
This is the main difference between a live rally and a multi feed drill.
So why are there three types of drills?
You might think the answer is as basic as well.
Shadowy is the easiest, so you start with that and then gradually move on to multi feed and then live rally.
But that is not correct at all.
It's true that for beginners, shadowing is easier compared to a live rally where you'll constantly be picking up the shuttle and making mistakes.
But even professional players use a lot of shadow in their training, so there must be more to it than that.
It all comes down to this concept of specificity versus transferability.
You can think of it like a spectrum.
A drill can either be very specific, very transferable, or lie anywhere along the spectrum, but importantly, it can't be both at the same time.
There's a trade off that takes place.
If a drill is specific, it means refining a certain aspect of that sport.
For example, imagine a 100 metre sprinter.

A specific exercise might be spending a few hours working just on his explosive start out of the blocks, he do a variety of drills that covers the initial part of this race without running the rest of it.
Since he has less to worry about, he can focus his attention on developing the acceleration phase.
If a drill is transferable, it closely replicates a real competition scenario, meaning it transfers well into a real game.
An example of a very transferable exercise with our sprinter Would be just to run the whole 100 metre race from start to finish.
This is pretty much as transferable as you can get since it's just mimicking the real requirements of a competition.
So you see why we have to implement both elements into our training.
It wouldn't be easy to develop a specific skill like starting from the blocks if all you did was run the full 100 metres over and over again.
There's too many things to think about in a full run so you'll never be able to Hone in that skill specifically.
As a result, your starting skills would never improve.
Likewise, you can't only practise specific skills if all you ever did in training was just the first part of the race.
You'd be screwed in a real competition where you actually need to run a full 100 metres.
It's the same thing in badminton.
We need a good mix of specific training to help us Hone in certain aspects of our footwork as well as transferable training so we can actually implement it into a real game.
And remember, an exercise isn't specific or transferable it lies anywhere along the spectrum.
A good training programme will take advantage of the whole spectrum to develop your footwork skills.
As I'm sure you've figured out by now, shallow exercises tend to be more specific.
Since you're not hitting a shuttle you can focus more on what your feet are actually doing.
Likewise, a live rally tends to be the most transferable since you're actually hitting a shuttle.
Just like in a real game, multi feed drills tend to lie somewhere in the middle.
But notice how I said tends to be because there are shallow drills that are more transferable.
Just like there are live rallies which are more specific.
But that's enough of the theory for now.
I just wanted to give you a good understanding before you dive into this module.
We'll kick things off in the next lesson lesson where I'll introduce some shadow exercises that will take your footwork to the next level get excited.
You're about to see all the hard work you've put in really start to show in your badminton games.
But fair warning, some of these are going to be brutal.
I'll see you there.
Bye.

lessons.name: Shadow Drills
lessons.description: Everyone has excuses. The difference between the best badminton players vs average ones is simple: they don't let their excuses stop them. You will be successful as long as you put in the work.

sentences.text: At this point in the course, you will have completed a fair bit of shadow work.
When going through the assignments here, we're going to turn it up a notch.
The shadow work you've done so far has been very basic, mainly to give you the repetitions needed to build muscle memory here.
Not only are we going to increase the intensity density to push your speed and endurance, these exercises are closer to resembling a real rally situation, so are more transferable.
In this lesson, we're going to cover a total of five shadow drills.
They are four corner shadow, aggressive shadow, defensive shadow, reactive shadow, and a custom drill.
Let's start with the four corner shadow.
As you can imagine, this involves shadowing to the four corners.
This is the simplest drill and will combine a lot of shadow work you've done in Module Three.

Starting off in the middle of the court, you're going to first shadow to the back and front court, recover back to the middle and then go to the forehand front core, recover to the middle and then go to the forehand rear core.
Recover, then finish off by shadowing to the backhand rear core and then repeat as you shallow to each corner.
You can use any footwork pattern you like.
For example, in the forehand rear corner you can scissor kick, China jump or step out.
It's up to you.
However, when you're just starting out, I recommend you keep it simple for now so you don't overwhelm yourself.
So, for example, you might want to stick with the scissor kick for a few rounds before switching to the China Jump.
This allows you to be a bit more consistent if you're not too familiar with the movements yet.
As this is the simplest drill just to get you started, you don't need to focus so much on speed yet.
The next few drills will do that.
The goal here is to get you using the footwork for module three in a more realistic scenario instead of being isolated to one corner at a time.
As a result, I still want you to focus on technique as you go through this drill, focus on moving with the same technical accuracy as you did in the module three assignments.
If you took the time to make these movement patterns muscle memory, then it should be easy.
If not, it's definitely worth redoing some of the previous assignments or adding in some extra reps before you move on.
Next we'll go over the aggressive shadow drill.
As you can imagine, this is a lot of fun, but fair warning.
The intensity of the drills are going to really increase from this point onwards, even though you still need to maintain the technique.
I expect you to push up the speed and you should be quite out of breath afterwards, and that's a good thing.
An effective footwork routine is one of the most tiring things in badminton, but in my opinion, also one of the most enjoyable.
As you can imagine, working this hard is going to put you leagues ahead of the competition, so enjoy every minute of it.
Even if you feel like passing out again, you're going to start in the middle of the court, but this time you have a lot more freedom in how you move.
Instead of going routinely through the four corners, I want you to move around the court in any way you like, as long as you're shadowing an aggressive formation.
What do I mean by that?
Well, when you're shadowing pretend you're playing a real game of singles.
But instead of playing how you usually would go into a full out attack for every single shot.
So I like to start with a pretend low serve and then instantly start shadowing attacking movements at the rear court.
This is obvious.
It means playing aggressive downward shots like smashes or drops, and my footwork will reflect this.
I'll be moving fast to get behind the shuttle and may even be jumping in to meet the shuttle earlier.
I can also intercept shots around the mid court with the China jump, as if my opponent is playing a flat lift.
Then at the front of the court, I'll be applying pressure.
The main ways to do this are to go for kills, aggressive drives, or just take the shuttle early and play a tight net shop.
For this drill, I usually do it for time 20 seconds of work followed by 20 seconds of rest.
You can use a stopwatch or easily download a free interval training app on your smartphone.
Now that might not sound like a very long time, but trust me, if you do this correctly and work at maximum intensity, 20 seconds for multiple reps is going to be brutally tough.
Just make sure you're working at close to maximum intensity.
Don't be lazy about it in terms of which corner to move to.
There's no correct way of doing this drill, so feel free to use your intuition and move to whichever corner you like.
However, make sure every shot is aggressive.
I don't want you to be playing defensive shots like backhand or taking the shuttle late.
That comes in the next drill.
Speaking of which, the next drill is going to be focused all around defensive shadow.
Now, this is the exact same, except we're going to pretend that we're defending for the whole rally instead of attacking.
So in this case, we're generally going to be getting to the shuttle late in the rear court.
This means using our defensive footwork and playing a neutralised or a backhand at the front of the court.
You'll be taking the shuttle from down low as if you're barely getting to it in time.
Also, you'll be defending your opponent's smashes in the mid court, where you'll also be required to get low and reach out.
I want to clear up a very important misconception.
Just because you're defending does not mean you get to take it easy.
In fact, I often tell people that you need to move faster when you're defending, since your opponent is forcing you under pressure.
If you're too slow, you'll lose the rally.
So when you do this drill, I still want you to be working at maximum intensity.
You'll only be doing 22nd sets, but if you do it correctly, you should be exhausted by the end.
Something I like to do is to combine the aggressive and defensive shadow into one workout.
So I'll do 20 seconds of aggressive footwork rest for 20 seconds and then do 20 seconds of defensive footwork rest for 20 seconds and repeat.
This is one of my absolute favourite drills because not only is it incredibly challenging, it also gives me the chance to work on all aspects of my footwork.
The next drill is Reactive Shadow.
This requires a partner to assist you, but it's a great drill because you don't get to decide which corner to move to.
Just like in a real game, start in the middle of the court with your partner standing in front of you.
He's going to point to one of the six corners on court, and it's your job to move to that corner.
Your partner can move you to the rear court, the front court, or the mid court on either the forehand or backhand side.
It's up to them.
Again, this is quite a simple drill, but there's a few things to note.
After moving to each corner, you need to immediately start recovering back to your base, just like you would in a real game.
Your partner should point to the next corner just before you complete your recovery.
So you're never stood waiting on court.
And yes, you can do the same corner twice in a row because this will often be the case in a real game.
Just make sure you're recurring between each shot.
You can do this drill for time again around 20 seconds, but I find it's more convenient to just count ten corners and this will be about 20 seconds.
Whichever you choose, rest 20 seconds between sets.
Alternatively, you can take turns helping each other out after you finish your set, your partner can work while you assist them by pointing to the corners.
Now onto the final drill.
This isn't a set drill because I want to give you a bit more freedom.
There are a million different ways you could shadow on court, so it's impossible to cover every single one.
So for this, I want you to choose out a drill that's perfect for you.
And don't worry, I'll help you choose one.
For this, I want you to think of an area that you struggle with in game.
It doesn't have to be something complicated.
In fact, I would prefer it if you kept it simple for me.
Since returning from badminton after a three year break, I found myself really struggling in the around the head corner.
This used to be one of my best areas, so I guess I just lost it somewhere down the line.
So for me, I would probably do a very simple drill to get me more comfortable moving to this corner.
I would start by shadowing a block on the forehand corner, recover, and then move to my round the head corner shadow a shot from here, recover and repeat this simple movement a few times.
If you're struggling to come up with a custom drill to work on, feel free to copy mine.
In fact, I find that this is a common weakness among a lot of players, so it would definitely be useful.
But if you know that there's another area of the court that you struggle with, I highly recommend you target it.
If you're struggling to identify it, think about which area of the court you lose the most points on.
That's probably a good indication that your footwork is weak in that area.
Shadow drills are great because you can do them on your own, and since there's no shuttle involved, you can work at a much faster pace than you would otherwise be able to manage.
When you combine all five exercises, it results in a very tough but rewarding workout.
You'll probably be left panting for breath, but at the same time, you can see how the hard work is going to pay off.
To recap, the five drills in this video were four corner shadow, aggressive shadow, defensive shadow, reactive shadow, and custom shadow.
Your assignment is to use these five drills to do a footwork focused training session.

If that sounds like a lot, remember that top professionals spend a lot of time training every day just on their footwork, so I recommend that you find a court for an hour and dedicate that time to footwork drills.
Start off with the four corner shadow.
I want you to do three sets of the shadow work for 1 minute and then rest for 30 seconds between each set.
Remember, this drill doesn't have to be carried out at full intensity.
You should slow it down so you can focus on technique.
That's why you're able to work for a full minute when doing this.
Next, we have aggressive and defensive shadow.
Like I said, I like to combine these into one workout, so start off by doing 20 seconds of aggressive shadow.
Rest for 20 seconds, then do 20 seconds of defensive shadow, rest for 20 seconds and repeat.
Do this for 16 rounds, meaning you should do eight sets of aggressive shadow and eight sets of defensive shadow work with high intensity for every set.
Warning, this workout will be tough, but if you're like me, you'll love it.
After that, you'll be moving on to the assisted shadow.
Feel free to take a couple of minutes to get your breath back before you move on.
Work for 20 seconds or ten corners, depending on how you're timing it.
Then rest for 20 seconds before continuing.
Repeat this five times.
The final drill is your own custom one.

Obviously it's hard to give you exact sets and reps since different drills are going to vary but a good benchmark to aim for is to spend five to ten minutes working on it, including work and rest periods.
By the end of all that you're going to be exhausted.
Congratulations on making out alive.
This is something I use to teach footwork to my students and they always end up hating me by the end of it but they also start moving a lot faster around the court so I guess they come around.
In fact by the next session they usually hungry for more.
So in the next lesson I'm going to be giving you some more drills to work on.
This time they're going to be multi feed drills.
I'll see you there.
Bye.

lessons.name: Multifeed Drills
lessons.description: Everyone wants to have good footwork, but what exactly does that mean? These five functions define how effective a player's footwork is.

sentences.text: Congratulations on surviving the multi feed drills.
I didn't actually tell you this in the last lesson, but that was the hardest part of this entire module.
So take a breath.
You survived when we're just shadowing the movement is the only thing we're thinking about.
So naturally the intensity is very high.
Lessons are going to be on multi feed and live rallies.
Don't get me wrong, they're still hard, but since there's a shuttle in play, we can slightly lower the intensity to focus more on consistency.
This is especially true for beginners.
That's an important note for the feeders.
Your goal isn't to beat the worker, it's to help them improve.
So don't try to feed as fast as you can, especially if you see the worker is struggling and missing a lot of shots.
As a general rule of thumb, the workers should be able to retrieve about 90% of shots in a multi feed drill.
If they aren't, slow down your feet to a pace that they're more comfortable with.
Obviously, you'll need a partner to help you work through this lesson, but don't worry, you don't need to hire a super expensive coach.
I recommend you find a friend or training partner and take time to feed each other.
This way you both help each other improve.
And don't worry if neither of you are experienced feeders.
I've deliberately selected drills that are easy to feed.
For a quick safety note before we begin, you might miss a few shuttles and that's perfectly fine.
The focus here is on the movement and not necessarily the quality of shot.
If you miss the shuttle, you can just ignore it and continue with the drill.
The one exception to this, however, is if you miss the shuttle and it's somewhere in the court where it becomes a trip hazard, stop immediately and move it out of the way first and then continue.
Obviously this is pretty common sense, but I just wanted to remind you because I do know people who have injured themselves by tripping over a shuttle.
My note sounds silly.
For all the drills in this lesson, you're going to be feeding a tube of ten shuttles for three sets.
So a total of 30 shuttles.
I've compiled my five favourite multi feed drills for this lesson.
They are half court, front and back, clear into a cross court block, smash to kill, block to neutralise and net shot multidrill.
I've selected these drills because they're simple enough for anyone to get started, but that doesn't mean they aren't challenging.
This drill is also quite simple, but it's really useful for learning to cover the long diagonal, a very important part of badminton.
Start off in the middle of the court.
The feeder is going to play a shot to your backhand side.
Use your footwork to play an around the head clear with a scissor kick and start recovering to the middle.
The next shot will be a block from the forehand side.
Play this and then repeat.
This drill is again pretty simple in its execution, so you shouldn't have too much trouble feeding it.
However, it's deceptively effective.
Like I said in the last video, the long diagonal is a weak point for many players.
Once you've done all three tubes, switch over to the other side.
It's the same thing, except you'll be doing a forehand clear and a backhand block.
When you approach the clear on the forehand side, you can either play it with a scissor kick or a China jump.
It's up to you and depends on how early you can get to the shuttle.
Start off focusing on the technique, but as you get more consistent, the speed of feeding can increase, so you'll get to work on your explosive movement.
As a note to the feeders, I recommend that you stand on the same side that you're blocking to.
This isn't hugely important, but I find it easier to feed than the other way around.
The next drill is an aggressive smash and kill drill.
The version I've described takes place on a full court, but if this is too advanced, feel free to adapt it to a half court like we did in the first drill.
Start off in the middle of the court.
You'll play a smash from the forehand side and then instantly come in to play a kill.
Recover quickly, then move to play a smash from around the head side.
Again, follow up straight and play a kill from here.
Just repeat the pattern on the forehand side.
You can China jump or scissor kick, depending on how much time you have to get behind the shuttle.
On the backhand side, you'll always want to use a scissor kick.
The key part of this drill comes immediately after you play the smash.
I don't want you to be lazy.
The very second you play the smash, I want you to start moving aggressively forward to the net.
You can do this by springing off your back leg after landing from hitting the shuttle.
This is something we've covered multiple times in the course.
Remember that when you play a good smash, you need to commit to coming into the net to apply pressure or in this case, play a kill.
Since this is quite an intense drill, it's important to feed at a pace that the worker is comfortable with.
If you feed too fast, the worker won't get much benefit out of this.
When you feed the lifts, I want them to land somewhere around three quarters to the back of the court.
Don't feed all the way to the back, since that's not appropriate for the context of this drill, which is an attacking drill.
Next, we have a drill to focus on defensive shots from the rear court, often called a neutralise.
If you don't know what a neutralise is, it's a shot we play from the rear corner when we're under pressure.
Since we're under pressure, we'll be moving to the shot on the forehand corner.
With the step out technique, you'll be taking the shuttle from slightly behind you and playing a flat shot to the front of the court.
It's similar to a drop shot, but with a few differences.
Since you're under pressure, don't worry too much about the technical side of the shop for now.
I just wanted to give you some additional context.
The focus here, of course, is on the footwork.
You're going to start off by playing a forehand block and then taking a small recovery step.
Don't travel too far, but you should be moving backwards and towards the middle.
The next shot will be a flat lift to your forehand side.
From here, you're going to use your step up footwork to play a neutralised shot.
Recover back to the middle and repeat.
At first, this might seem similar to the first drill we did with the simple front to back movement, but that isn't quite accurate.
Firstly, you should be shadowing this drill as if you're playing a real game on a full court.

That means when you play the first block, you need to recover back towards the middle, not to the actual middle of the court, but you need to move in that direction instead of just going straight back.
Secondly, you're supposed to be late to the shuttle for this drill since you'll be fed a flat lift.
Overall, the idea is to work on a situation where you're late to the shuttle in the rear court.
This is a very frequent scenario that we want to train for, so you want to be under some pressure in this drill.
Obviously, this doesn't mean the feeder should go overboard.
If you notice that the worker is struggling to retrieve about 90% of the shots, then make sure to slow it down to a pace that they're more comfortable with.
Repeat this for three cubes, then move on to the backhand side.
It's a very similar drill on this side, except you'll be playing a backhand shot instead of a forehand neutralised.
Remember how in module three we said that these three movements are parallel to each other?
For when you're under pressure in the forehand or backhand rear core, start off with a backhand block, recover towards the middle, then use your backhand footwork to play a backhand drop shot.
Recover back to the middle and repeat.
Now, I know a lot of players struggle to hit backhand shots, but it's perfectly fine to miss the shuttle as long as your footwork is good.
Remember that these drills are about movement, not shot quality.
That being said, it will be more fun and it is beneficial to work with more consistency.
So ask your feeder to slow down from the forehand side if necessary.
Repeat this drill for three tubes and then move on.
This last drill is one of my favourites.
Even though the concept is incredibly simple, it's a really enjoyable challenge.
It takes place entirely at the front of the court and is a fastpaced drill.
You start off in the middle of the court a little bit behind the service line.
The feeder will rapidly feed you a bunch of shuttles to random positions at the front of the court.
They can be to the forehand, backhand or middle of the court and can vary in height and tightness.
It's your job to get them all back.
Don't worry too much about shot quality.
The goal is just to hit the shuttle back over the net.
However, I want you to make sure that you're still recovering back into position after each shot.
It's very easy to start inching forwards in an attempt to return more shuttles but I want you to move as if you were in a real game.
That means taking a recovery step after each shot.
Of course, you don't need to recover all the way back to the middle since you tend to stay closer to the net.
After playing a net shot, the feeder can hand feed or use his racket for this drill it just comes down to preference.
It's incredibly important for the feeder to adjust the speed of the structure appropriately.
It should be fast enough to be challenging without being too hard.
You'll know you're feeding correctly if the worker is returning a lot of shots from close to the floor but is still able to work at above 90% consistency.
Again, I want you to feed three tubes of this drill.
Multi feed drills are another great way of developing your footwork.
When you do them, you get the chance to hit shuttles while still working at a higher intensity than would be possible in a real rally.
Essentially, they're a great balance between specificity and transferability.
To recap, the five multi feedback from this video were half court front and back clear to cross court block smash to kill block to neutralise net shot multi feed.
As expected, your assignment is to work through all the drills in this video.
You can do it in a separate session from the shallow drill or you can do it straight afterwards but you might need a break.
Whichever you choose, find a friend or training partner and take turns feeding each other.
This way you can help each other grow.
All right, I'll see you in the next lesson where we go over the final type of drill live rallies.

lessons.name: Live Rallies
lessons.description: How are the world's top performers able to be so...excellent? It all comes down a deceptively simple concept called muscle memory.

sentences.text: Are you feeling emotional?
I am.
Welcome to the last lesson of the football fast Lane.
It's crazy how we've gotten here so quickly, but before I get too soppy, we still have a lesson to complete.
This lesson is about the final type of training drill.
Live Rallies Live rallies take place with one shot at a time, just like in a real game.
But unlike a real game where we have the freedom to hit any shot we want, these live rallies revolve around a certain movement pattern.
As expected, this is the most transferable type of drill.
But since there's only one shuttle in play, it's really important to keep the consistency there.
You don't want to be constantly picking up shuttles from the floor.
That's just not an efficient way to learn.
So when you go through these drills, lower the intensity so you can keep the rallies going on for as long as possible.
That's especially important to keep in mind for the feeders.
Again, you'll need a friend or training partner to help you.
If possible, try to find a skilled player, or at least someone you know can feed with consistency.
If you can't find someone like that, that's fine.
You can still do these drills, and if they've proved to be too difficult at your current skill level, then just put them in the pocket for later.
You'll already get a tonne out of the shadow and multi feed drills.
So just come back when you've had a little more practise and remember, you have lifetime access to all of the lessons in the footwork Fastlane.
I've tried to keep these drills simple so they're as accessible as possible, but don't confuse simple with ineffective.
Even top professional players trained with these drills.
Let's get started.
The Five Types of Live Rallies You're going to do a half court, drop net lift, one v.
Two defence, one v.
Two attack block neutralise one corner challenge.
The first drill drop net lift is the easiest of the bunch.
Just like the last few lessons.
The purpose is just to ease you into doing live rallies.
In this drill, there is no feeder.
You're both working and feeding at the same time.
The drill takes place on a half court.
Start off with a high serve.
My partner plays a drop shot and I come in to play a net shot.
My partner then comes into the net to play a lift, which sends me to the back of the court.
I play a drop shot, he plays a net shot, I lift, and the whole cycle repeats.
It's very simple.
It just follows the pattern of drop net lift and repeats itself.
There isn't much to say about this drill.
Just try to keep the rally going on for as long as possible.
Remember that the goal isn't to beat your partner, it's to keep the consistency there so you both develop effective front to back movement patterns.
Do this drill for about five minutes before moving on.
The next drill is One v two defence.
This works best with two feeders, but if you can't find someone else to help you out, then this still works.
With just one feeder.
The two feeders will stand in a front to back formation while you'll be covering the whole court on your own.
You will spend the whole time defending while the feeders attack with smashes and drops.
Start off with a high serve and the feeder at the back will attack.
Your job is to defend their shot by playing a block to the net.
From here, the feeder at the front will play a net shot, which will come in for and lift.

Keep this rally going for as long as possible by constantly retrieving the Feeder's attack, the feeders should play with enough aggression to keep the worker under pressure at all times, but don't attack so fiercely that the rallies consistently last less than two or three shots.

It's going to be most beneficial for the worker if you can keep the rallies long and consistent, so adjust the difficulty if you see the workers struggling and make sure you make as few unforced errors as possible.
This is a great drill for the worker to develop their defensive football and it's also very transferable, so you should quickly see improvements to your defence.
Each worker should do this drill for five minutes before moving on to the next one.
The next drill is quite similar, except the worker is going to develop his aggressive footwork.
The two feeders will adopt a side by side formation while the worker will be alone.
Start off the rally however you like.
The feeders can start with a high serve, but if I'm the worker, I prefer to start off with a low serve since this is how I play singles.
Either way, the feeders are going to hit the shuttle to the rear court and I'm going to attack.
I can play a smash, drop shot or slice essentially any attacking shot, and it's the Feeder's job to defend it.
After the feeder has blocked the net, I'll come in and play a net shot.
They'll lift and the cycle repeats.
Now it's very tempting for the feeders to want to show off.
Since there's two of you, it's very easy to counterattack.
You might be able to play a really flat defence or come in and drive it back at them, but don't do this.
It's not useful at all for the worker and it's only possible because there's two of you defending.
It never happens in a real game.
Of course, you want to push the worker, but it needs to be in a realistic scenario.
Instead, play a comfortable straight block to the net and keep it simple.
The same thing applies when you're lifting.
You want to give them a lift that allows them to get behind the shuttle and attack.
In fact, your lift can be anywhere from half court to three quarters of the court.
Since that's where most smashes occur from.
Don't play an insanely flat lift that puts them under pressure and definitely don't try to use deception.
That's just way too difficult for this level.
Just like before, this is a very transferable drill that will help you develop an aggressive playstyle.
It's also a lot of fun because you get to play a lot of smashes, but don't forget to mix in your slices and dropshots just like you would in a real game unless you're this guy.
Wow, my smash is really good.
Do this drill for about five minutes per worker and then move on.
The next drill is quite similar to the neutralised drill we did in the last lesson, but this time we're going to do it as a live rally instead of a Multifeed.
The feed will stand@the.net on the forehand side of the court and you'll be on the opposite side.
Even though we're only going to be working on the forehand side of the court, I want you to position yourself as if you were playing a real game on a full court.
This means moving towards the middle of the court.
Start off by blocking back and forth to each other on the forehand side, recovering back each time.

Then when the feeder decides he will randomly throw in a flat lift to your forehand side, your goal is to get to it with a step up movement in time to play a neutralise, recover back to the middle, continue to block back and forth, and repeat.
Unlike the multi feed drill where it was always one block and one lift, this time you keep playing blocks until the feeder decides to lift.
The benefit of this is it keeps you on your toes, just like in a real game, because you don't know when your opponent is going to play this shot.
You can then repeat this drill on the backhand side, just as you would expect.
It's the exact same thing.
Now you'll be playing backhand blocks and when the feeder decides to throw in a flat lift, you'll move to it with the backhand footwork and play a backhand drop shot.
Repeat this for five minutes, two and a half minutes on each side, and then move on to the next drill.
The final drill is the one corner challenge.
It requires a feeder who will stand in one corner at the front of the court, either on the forehand or backhand side.
The two of you will play a live rally where the worker has to return everything to the same corner, but the feeder has the freedom to hit it wherever they like.
This is quite a challenging drill as you'll be put under pressure a lot, and no matter where you are on court, you have to keep hitting the shuttle to the same corner.
This is a great way to train your retrieval skills as you'll be moving to all four corners and you can use different footwork patterns depending on how much time you have to get to the shuttle.
As usual, the job of the feeder is to keep the rally going for as long as possible while making sure the worker is still under pressure.
Work at this for two and a half minutes then have the feeder switch sides to the other corner.
It's the exact same exercise with the worker returning everything to this corner.
Work at this for two and a half minutes and that concludes the live rallies.
Live rallies are a great way of building your footwork in a very transferable way so you'll develop other aspects of your game as you work through these drills to recap.
The five exercises I want you to do are half court DropNet list one v.
Two defence one v.
Two attack block neutralised drill one corner challenge that leads me nicely to your assignment for this video.
I want you to work through all of these drills spending five minutes on each one again.
You can do it in the same session as the other assignments in this module or you can wait a few days and do it another time.
It's up to you.
These drills are the final step of the football fast Lane.
The live rallies are key to implementing what you've learned into your bandwidth and games.

I'm really happy you've made it to the end of this course and I can't wait to hear about how much improvement you've made in your games but to be honest I'm also a little bit sweet that it's coming to an end.
We'll end the course with one final debrief.

lessons.name: Conclusion
lessons.description: How are the world's top performers able to be so...excellent? It all comes down a deceptively simple concept called muscle memory.

sentences.text: Here we are at the end of the footwork Fastlane.

And what an incredible journey it's been, both for you to grow and develop your footwork, but also for me, this is the first time I've ever created something like this, and it's been a humbling experience.

So no matter what stage in your bandits and journey you're at, knowing that I've created something for you that I would have sold my kidneys for ten years ago makes all the long hours and late nights making this course completely worth it.

Bennett, so I want to congratulate you for going on this amazing journey with me.

When I look back at my own Bambin journey, I'm constantly astounded to see how far I've come.

lessons.name: Diving Masterclass
lessons.description: We all dream of pulling off the perfect dive, recovering, then winning the rally. In this bonus lesson, former England International player Ben Beckman will teach you exactly how to do that.

lessons.name: Mobility Manual
lessons.description: Welcome to the Mobility Manual! This will help you develop the lower body mobility needed to get into the correct positions for efficient footwork.

lessons.name: Jeremy
lessons.description: Welcome to the Student Analysis bonus course! Here, I will be doing a breakdown/analysis of several Footwork Fastlane student's movement. There should be something for everyone to learn here.

lessons.name: Introduction
lessons.description: Welcome to the Explosive Strength bonus course, where you’ll build the lower body strength to supplement your new found footwork skills.

lessons.name: Key Principles of Strength Training
lessons.description: Strength training can be a beast, before you start it’s important that you understand these key principles.

lessons.name: Exercises
